country:

text:
I loved this, but made some changes after reading ALL of the reviews and making it several times.  To cut back on the sweetness and on the juice, I used NO added sugar in the fruit.   I used orange marmalade for the preserves and froz peaches in place of raspberries and there was plenty of juice and it was quite sweet.  (Sugar draws juice out, so it will have more liquid with the added sugar!)
Also, I used Fuji apples which have less tendency to turn brown, and added the apples last so that they could be stirred into the other fruit to coat the apples.  I had NO browning that way.
To save time with  the chips, I first sprayed 4 tortillas at a time with butter spray, front and back, and then cut them with the pizza cutter.   Then I put the sugar mix ...1 c sugar to 1 t cinnamon,,,into a bowl and dredged the chips 2 at a time.   One batch of the sugar mix did 2+ batches of the chips.  I simply 'baggied' the remainder and used it another time.  I did NOT spray them after sugaring.  They don't need it if you spray both sides first.
They did best at about 9-10 minutes baking.   
Overall, everyone loved this and neither the fruit nor chips were to sweet.

text:
Here's a tip to save time chopping:

Buy an egg slicer (available on the kitchen aisle of most grocery stores for about $4). It works great on strawberries!!!
Just put Them in and slice them and then turn the other way and slice again. It dices them perfectly. I also use it for other soft fruits (kiwi, peaches etc. Just peel & cut into chunks first & use it the same way as with strawberries.

text:
I have made this recipe numerous times & everyone ALWAYS LOVES IT!  It can take some time to make.  I recommend chopping fruit with a food chopper (pampered chef has an excellent one).  When I am really crammed with time I buy my cinamom sugar chips from Trader Joe's or if I'm lucky I sometimes find them at a grocery store.  When I make the chips myself, after thoroughly cleaning my sink out I put a dinner plate in the sink & stack all the tortillas on it & spray both sides of the tortilla (4 at a time) with I can't believe its not butter or some other butter flavor spray.  I then place the cinamon/sugar mix in the container the cinamon usually comes in (since it has the top with holes to sprinkle with) & sprinkle both sides of the tortilla BEFORE CUTTING it.  This helps tremendously with the mess!  Out of the sink on a seperate plate I cut 4 tortillas at a time with a pizza cutter.  I didn't follow the cooking time the recipe reccomends (my oven is old) I would tap a couple of chips & once they felt a little crispy & were golden brown they are done! (the chips turn crispier as they cool) I usually use apricot preserves, & granny smith apples or fuji apples.  As previous reviewers recomend, I cut the apples last to prevent browning.  I sprinkle cinnamon & sugar to my taste for the salsa mix (I cut out brown sugar...to skip a step) I thought with the chips the recipe just didn't need as much sugar.  This recipe is very versatile so play around with it!  I hope this helps!

text:
I made this recipe for a school function of about 30 people.  Only 3 or 4 enjoyed the salsa.  I added some fresh shredded coconut as well as mango.  Almost everyone loved the cinnamon tortillas.  To make my life easier I sprayed the cut tortillas with the cooking spray, threw them all into a gallon size zippered storage bag, and then added my cinnamon and sugar mix.  After a few shakes all the chips were coated on both sides and I just layed them on the pans.  Worked a lot easier than doing it one at a time.  Overall, it was a miniature version of a fruit salad.  But the chips were good without the "salsa".

Took this to a ladies luncheon at my church and it was devoured!  My husband asked me to make it again because there weren't any leftovers for him!  Just a tip...Tostito's now has available the flour tortilla chips, you can just heat them up on a cookie sheet in the oven and the oils will reappear, which will allow the cinnamon-sugar to stick to the chip...just toss the chips and sugar together in a large ziploc bag it will save you a lot of time!

text:
Wow! This needs to come with a warning: Highly Addictive! This was a beautiful combination of colors and flavors. And, what's great about this is it's low fat and good for you too. No matter what assortment of fresh fruit you use it's bound to be good so use your favorites and use the recipe as a guide. I used a combination of apples, strawberries, peaches, and kiwi. I left out the sugar as the fruit has enough of that on it's own. For the preserves, again use your favorite. I chose seedless raspberry. For the cinnamon chips I used reduced fat tortillas and cut them with a pizza cutter which made things a lot easier. I sprayed them with butter flavored Pam and sprinkled them with the cinnamon sugar. I baked them at 350 for 8 minutes flipped them and baked them for another 7 minutes. They were crispy, sweet and delicious - next time I would double the amount because they went fast. This got a lot of compliments not only for taste, but for creativity. I'll definitely make this again - great recipe!

text:
I took this dish to a tropical theme birthday party and it was a hit. I made the chips the day before. I first cut the tortillas in a triangle, laid them side by side on a parchment lined cookie sheet. I then sprayed them with spray butter and sprinkled them with the cinnamon and sugar . When baking, make sure the chips are crisp before removing from oven, in my opinion it is better for them to be over-crisp then under crisp.  The other thing I did is use fresh pineapple, hollowing out the center and using the shell as a dish.

text:
HELPFUL TIPS AFTER READING ALL THE REVIEWS: If you're in a crunch, try some cinnamon wheat thins or cinnamon pita chips down the snack aisle.  The tortillas tend to take some time to make, so I'd get started on them first so you're salsa doesn't get all soggy if you're making a big batch of chips! And use 1C sugar&1tsp cinnamon.  They're addicting & can see why so many people (including myself) eat them "as is."  I wasn't sure I'd believe that you don't have to over drench your tortillas in cinnamon, but it's true.  One quick dip & there's plenty of yummyness.  I've NEVER had any problems w/the apple (fuji) browning, but if you do ...dip the slices in lemon juice to prevent it.  I just eye the amount I want to add for everything to suit the number of people we are feeding.  There's no need for adding sugar b/c the fruit preserves & the fruit adds enough flavor.  I have better luck w/finding fresh blueberries than I do raspberries, and I prefer them!  People are always impressed with this dish & you really are a hero to all the hungry tummies, so thanks for posting this recipe!

text:
This appetizer was so well received! Everyone loved it. I was very pleased.

I cut 8-inch tortillas into quarters with scissors, brushed both sides of each triangle with melted butter, and tossed them all in a large ziploc bag with a cup of cinnamon and sugar for a good shaking. Some came out less covered than others -- great for different tastes among the guests.

Tip: Using a muffin tray instead of a baking sheet shaped the triangles into scoops! Perfect for dipping into the salsa.

text:
This was delicious.  I did cut the sugars and I felt my salsa was a bit tart, although those eating it did not agree.  I dipped my apples in lime juice to avoid browning and found a slightly different recipe for the chips.  Brush them lightly with water, place on foil lined cookie sheet sprayed with cooking spray, sprinkle generously with cinnamon sugar and bake 4-5 min at 500 degrees.  These chips turned out better for me.  Kids and husband enjoyed the left overs.  This was great, thanks for sharing.

text:
This recipe is wonderful.  I changed it a bit to fit in to my diet plan and make the recipe smaller.  I used 2 kiwi's, 1 apple, 1 cup strawberries, and 1/2 cup frozen berry mix.  I also sub'd splenda and light sugar free strawberry preserves.  I used 98% fat-free tortillas and a cinnamon and splenda blend for the chips.  I also pre-cut the tortillas with a pizza cutter and dip them in to the cinnamon mix.  I cooked each batch of chips 5 min on each side.  This made of a wonderfully sweet, filling, and low-fat snack.  I will absolutely make this again.  Thanks Ann!!!! :)

text:
I served this at a 50th wedding reception and it was a big hit. Since berries were out of season, I used frozen "Berry Mix" with strawberries, blueberries,blackberries and raspberries. Then added an apple, kiwi and fresh peach. Pulsed all fruit VERY quickly in food processor and was done. No cutting required but do be careful about not over-pulsing or you will have a liquid.  It was pretty and tasted great.

text:
This was fantastic!  I'd had something similar before, and it was everything I was hoping for.  I will say that I don't think the time listed for the recipe takes chopping time into account.  I ended up doubling the amount of chips that I made, and because I made sure to only put a single layer on the pan, it took me a couple of hours to make two batches.  It was well worth it though. I took the advice of other reviewers and shook them in a big bag with the cinnamon sugar and it seemed to work well. As for the salsa, I made it twice in two days. The first time, I followed the recipe exactly. I tried using my egg slicer for the kiwi and ended up breaking the slicer. I just cut everything by hand, making very tiny pieces because it needs to fit on a chip. It turned out very pretty and everyone at my bookclub loved it and couldn't believe that I made it, especially the chips. The second time I made the salsa, it was just for my husband and I, so it didn't need to be pretty.  This time, I just cut up each fruit and pulsed them in the food processor for a few seconds... so much faster!!!  I added blackberries and blueberries, and didn't have anymore raspberries, but it seems to be delicious no matter what fruit you add.  I will say that the addition of the blackberries kind of muddied the color, so if you are going for presentation, be cautious of that.  I love this recipe and will definitely make it again.

text:
Very tasty.  To cut time it takes to make chips.  Spray surface of wax paper with butter spray and lay out first tortilla.  Lay next tortilla on top and spray.  Continue until all 10 are in stack.  Cut while stacked and separate.  Place 1/4 of chips in plastic sealed bag with 1/4 of cinnamon mixture.  Shake to coat chips.  Lay out on tray and spray again.  Bake

I have to rate this more based upon client input than my own taste test. I tasted the salsa and chips separately, which were both good but I'm sure they're better together. I used square wontons instead of tortillas, sprayed each side with the butter spray, then dredged in the cinnamon sugar. I pressed the wonton squares into a mini cupcake pan and baked. Right before serving filled the cups with the salsa. I had people run up to me just to tell me how great they were.

text:
I made this for the first time last night and took it to a family BBQ - it was a HUGE hit with both adults and kids alike.  The recipe says it only makes 10 servings but we ate it as an appetizer and there was plenty for at least twice that.  For the chips, I used 20 smaller tortillas - I like this size better.  The cinnamon sugar is really easy to make too - just mix 1/2 cup white sugar for every 1 tbl of cinnamon.

text:
I wanted this to be more salsa than salad so shredded the apples and mashed everything with a potato masher.  I left out the sugar as per reviews  and while it does taste fantastic, it could definately use some sugar haha..  The chips are  awesome - I did the melted butter on one side, stacked and cut all 10 at once with a pizza cutter.  Shook em in a bag with cinn/sugar ... was so easy and no mess... thanks for the tips!  One thing I'll add bcuz I saw someone  mentioned it, is you do not turn these chips over as they bake.   Single layer, both sides crisp up perfectly.  I had two foil lined sheets going so it was pretty steady :)

text:
No doubt about it, one of the best recipes on this site!  I have made this countless times, using different combinations of fruit and jellies and have never had a bad batch.  The only thing I have changed over time is using 1/2 the amount of sugar and jelly.  The natural sweetness of the fruit and the liquids most fruit produce provide everything needed.  I have not heard a single complaint about this recipe.   Couple of side notes:   If you are pressed for time, skip the homemade chips, and buy a bag of cinnamon tortilla or pita chips.  If you happen to make a big batch and have leftovers, they make a GREAT crumble!  Thank you for sharing this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS IS SOOOOO GOOD – reading a PILE of the 3000+ reviews here are a few things I learned and did – one woman stated stale tortillas worked – she was right! Whole wheat tortillas need a little more time. Baking these 10-12 minutes worked. The fruit salsa – someone spoke of using none of the sugar the preserves used would be enough and YES preserves do the job. Looking at ALL the photos – I got a lot of ideas and used a lot of fruit. One woman used an hard boiled egg slicer to slice fruit with – as soon as I read that I started slicing strawberries for my husband right away – WHAT A TIP – then with the salsa – any fruit soft enough to go through the egg slicer – got the slicer – it made slicing so much quicker. The additional fruits I cut up to use were frozen peaces, mango, frozen blueberries, some black and green grapes, and mint from my garden as part of the visual embellishment. I also cut the apples last and added to the mix so there’d be no browning My son’s girlfriend loves it – everyone loves the chips.

Display Name:
Sally

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this the other day for a house warming party and it was absolutely FABULOUS!!!! Beautiful presentation/looks like it was much more work than it was.
I used all the fruits called for in the recipe but substituted orange marmalade for the raspberry preserves. This gave the salsa a great hint of citrus plus just one more great bit of color with the orange.
I too cut out the white sugar. It doesn't need it!!  I added fuji apples at the end instead of the golden delicious.
One suggestion I have when making the chips. Buy thin flour tortillas, not the thicker ones. After reading the reviews, here is how I made my chips. As suggested here, I put my tortilla shells on a plate in the sink, sprayed butter flavored pam on both sides, then sprinkled both sides with cinnamon sugar from a shaker. Then I cut the shells with a pizza cutter and baked for NO MORE than 9 minutes. They do get more crisp as they cool.
Great recipe and I'll be making it again and again!!!

text:
I really don’t understand why the recipe calls for sugar..I guess if the fruits aren’t in season you might need to sweet them up otherwise..you definitely don’t need the sugar. Time consuming: yes! Lot of cutting..maybe next time I’ll buy the chopper…I used, 2 golden apples, 2 kiwis, half cup of fresh pineapple, half cup of mango and only half pound of strawberries and it was enough! About the chips! Great hit! Bought 12” tortilla and cut them in 12 triangles. No doubt the idea of the muffin pan is the best! Make the chips scoopable :o) loved them!. Don’t get me wrong: everyone loved it and without the sugar and cirup the recipe is quite healthy but as some comments said: it’s a lot of time consuming for a fruit salad. Oh! I used “I cannot believe is not butter spay” on the first batch of chips and then I run out of it. So I used regular melted butter. I liked better the first batch! And on top of that NO CALORIES ON THE BUTTER!!! 
This is a keeper (as long as you have a chopper!)

text:
This is one my favorite all time recipes! I have been making this for years. It is always a crowd pleaser. To make it easier, I use frozen strawberries and raspberries. I chop each fruit in the food processor. And then I stir in a can of drained crushed pineapple. The chips are the most time consuming but SO worth the effort. They are the perfect "thinness". Buying store bought cinnamon chips are too thick. Overall this dish is AMAZING. I always hold on to some in a separate dish before I serve it so that I have some left for myself!

userID:
5424868
Display Name:
jesuismoi7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe! I wound up, somewhat accidentally, making a very different version than the one listed. I didn't add any of the sugar to the salsa. I also didn't add the preserves. I wish I could say that was a planned decision, but truthfully I just couldn't get the lid off the preserve jar. LOL. But it still ended up tasting delicious, the fruit is sweet enough on it's own. I also used pita bread instead of the tortillas. I just split 8 6" round pita pockets in two (leaving 16 6" round flat pitas), placed them on nonstick foil on a cookie sheet. Butter-sprayed the front and back of each one, stacked 2 or 3 together and sliced them with a pizza cutter. I made only 1/2 of the cinnamon-sugar mixture, put it in a salt shaker and sprinkled on both sides the chips. Then cooked for 10 minutes. Everything tasted great, texture of salsa and chips are perfect, and by not using sugar or preserves in the salsa, replacing the tortillas with pita and only using half the cinn-sugar mixture, it wound up a very healthy, low calorie treat. With 64 chips made, they were only 30 calories per chip, and less than 400 calories for the entire huge bowl of salsa.

text:
YUM!  And super addictive.  I used the recipe as a guideline but took the advice of others to cut the sugar down.  I used 1/4 cup of sugar TOTAL as the preserve has plenty of it.  A tip for the chips:  Be sure to coat the tortillas entirely with the cinnamon sugar for an even yummier chip.  I found it time consuming to bake the tortillas (laying the triangles in a single layer to bake) but worth the wait in the end.

country:
None
text:
I did not use the sugar or preserves and it was still amazing.  I sprayed my cutting board with butter and put one tortilla on it then sprayed the top of that one and stacked another, each time spraying only the top as the bottom would butter itself from the top of the tortilla underneath.  I then cut fajita size tortillas into 4 wedges and dredged them in a mixture of 1 tablespoon to 1 cup of sugar.  It's important not to get too much butter or the tortillas will have too much sugar and will burn easily.

text:
I took this to our work potluck yesterday and got rave reviews from everyone.  I did make a few slight changes based on what the other reviewers said.  I substituted mango for apples and left out the sugars.  I chopped everything rather than dicing as I wanted a more salsa like texture.  For the preserves I used Mango/Peach pepper jelly.  It was a nice surprise to folks who tasted it and said "hmmm...what is that little zing at the end?"  To save time with the chips I lightly brushed both sides of the tortillas with olive oil and shook the wedges in a bag rather than sprinkling the cinnamon sugar.  All in all these were a hit and will definitely make them again!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
As is, this recipe deserves 5 stars.  However, more recently, I've experimented with a spicy version which has also received rave reviews, although probably not for the grandparents. I add 2-3 finely-diced jalapenos, 1T Cayenne pepper and optionally, 1T fresh cilantro. This creates a perfect sweet/spicy combo for me, but I like things fairly spicy. Adjust to your own taste. We even topped slow-cooked pork with this spicy version...a huge hit!

text:
OMG this was a huge hit at Christmas and I have made another time since for a small get together in which everyone loved it! I went the easy route and bought cinnamon sugar pita chips which were delicious. I used an apple, two kiwi, half a pineapple, blackberries, and a tablespoon of apricot jam, omitting all other sugar. It was not needed. Will definately continue to make! A lot of work chopping and fruit can be expensive though. UPDATE: I buy cinnamon sugar chips from store. Jewel has their own brand. Stacys are good too. Meijer has their own brand also. So much easier! I also only use fruit, no need for sugar or preserves. I've added pineapple and blackberries, try using any variety of fruit and it works. Some are just watery than other so be careful to drain the pineapple a bit.

country:

text:
OMGosh!  This is so delicious.  I was looking for a healthy snack for tailgating and came across this recipe.  It was a hit.  I've made it twice and for the most part went right by the recipe.  Since fresh raspberries were not available at our grocer, I substituted the frozen whole raspberries.  I chopped them slightly in the food processor before adding them to the mixture.  It was delicious but did make the salsa a little more watery than if I had used fresh, but nevertheless, it was delicious.  The second time I made this recipe, I substituted frozen peaches for the raspberries and again chopped them in the food processor before adding them to the other fruit.  I also added some fresh blueberries just b/c I love them (and b/c I was going for an orange and blue tailgate theme...WAR EAGLE!).  Delicious again.  Both times, I chopped the apples into about 1/2 inch cubes and then tossed them in a couple of Tablespoons of lime juice to keep them from turning brown.  This will definitely be a keeper for all of our tailgating parties.  And by the way, I failed to mention that the chips are great as well...very flavorful and crispy.

text:
As great as everyone else said!! I have to admit, at first I didn't know why this would taste so good, but it really is AMAZING! Thanks to all the reviewers comments. I used a frozen Wal-mart mix of strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, and backberries, 3 fresh kiwi, 1 apple-dipped slices in lemon juice to prevent browing. I diced all except blueberries and raspberries small to scoop easily with the chips. NO sugar used or needed. 1 1/2TBS of strawberry preserves. Sat out for 2hrs before serving and it was perfect for the juices to form. Tortillas-4 to 1 ratio sugar to cinnamon. Butter spray to both sides and put in ziplock bag to shake then sliced w/pizza cutter and sprayed tops again and put in oven for 10 min @ 350. Came out perfect and crisp. Great by themselves as well. Made for a baby shower w/18 guests. Enough for all and so many raves. Everyone was impressed and couldn't believe I made the chips. Recipe very forgiving and only took me 40min to complete. Must try and I will be making this all the time! Cost me only $10.00. What a great fruit recipe without paying the high Fruit price

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do this fairly often and have it down to a science as well.  I deep fry four packages of small tortillas cut into eights and then shake them in a paper bag with a container of cheap cinnamon and a cup or so of sugar.  They stay crisp, wonderful and delicious and this way you have tons, but they still generally disappear before the salsa.  It seems to me to be faster than the oven baking as well.It is more fattening to be sure, but the taste is superior.  I also use two lbs of strawberries, two kiwis, two green apples and a pint of raspberries.  I mix this the night before with 2 T. brown sugar and 2 T. apricot preserves.  About an hour before, I add a pkg of frozen blueberries.  This seems to be the most cost-effective method for me, and it tastes fantastic!

text:
I doubled the recipe and brought this to our bi-weekly bible study group and its a good thing I did.......there ended up being close to 40 people there!  The fruit salsa looks fantastic....so many different colors. I used all the fruits called for, and added some mango.  Also used apricot preserves. I didn't double the sugar amounts......don't think that would have been necessary.  Both the salsa and the chips were a big hit.  The salsa was completely devoured and I  made two huge bags of chips and there was half a bag left by the end.  My only reservations was how time consuming this recipe was, between the chopping of the fruit and the preparation of the chips.  Also, I don't understand how it becomes "fruit salsa" when its basically chopped up fruit.  People seemed to really enjoy it though and I had two people ask where they could get the recipe, so I must say it was a success!  Also, a sidenote to some other reviewers:  don't use Pam for coating the chips.  That tends to be more of an olive oil base.  Get "I Can't Believe its not Butter" Spray or another brand for cooking and basting.  It can be found in the dairy section of your supermarket.  It worked great.

userID:
4240098
Display Name:
momuv4
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/397498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used nectarines, kiwi, and strawberries. With all citrus fruit, I wouldn't have to worry about browning. I only used my favorite raspberry preserves. Not very sweet, but that may depend on your fruit. I think I would prefer a much richer base, like adding raspberry pie filling, but this way it makes it a light dessert. Now with the chips: If the chips aren't good, nothing is good! Ladies, this is when you want to use your convection function on your oven if you have one! I convection baked at 350 for 7 min, turned, and 4 min. max! You don't want to over-bake as well as under-bake. I noticed if the chip is crispy around the edges, but slightly soft in the center, it WILL harden up later. The sugars harden and it turns out nicely. I sprayed both sides of a whole bag of small 12 tortillas, and stacked them and cut them with a  pizza cutter. Then threw them all in a bag filled with 1C sugar and 1T cinnamon. It coated evenly and everyone was happy with it.

userID:
7307424
Display Name:
Jaime Whitaker
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is sensational!!  I was a bit confused by some of the reviewers pictures, as fruit salsa I have had in the past was very finely diced and had a decent amount of liquid.  Some of the photos looked more like fruit salad to me.

That being said, I chose to FINELY dice my fruit and add an extra tablespoon of brown sugar to increase the juice.  It sat in my fridge all day for an evening party and was exactly the consistency I had hoped for..not to mention DELICIOUS!!

Do not forgo making the cinnamon/sugar tortilla chips, as they were amazing and I don't think the dip would have been the same without them.  I had to stop myself from snacking on them as they came out of the oven. :) I just don't think store bought chips would do this recipe justice.

In summary, a delicious, light summer recipe that is easy to make, if not a tad time consuming only because of the peeling and chopping...but well worth it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Potluck tested.  There was less than 1/2 left over.  Went soggy and very unappealing by the end of the meal.  Kiwi I found didn't hold up well.  You pretty much have to have very firm fruit, but then you risk lacking sweetness of the fruit as do the strawberries.  I say, why fight it.  If you want a salsa, then make it look like one, not a gone-limp fruit salad.  Try making a thin sauce using cornstarch out of a  bit of pureed fruit and then add that to the fruit and chill.   I would cut down or leave sugar out all together and let the fruit preserves make the syrup.

text:
This is a family favorite.  The first time we served it to my niece and nephews, my youngest nephew (8 at the time) just ate bowls of it.  We ate it on ice cream too.  I used a lot of the suggestions from the feedback here and found the tips on working with the tortillas the most helpful -- I definitely cut them up before shaking them and also bake them in muffin tins to get a good scoop shape.  I think someone suggested turning the muffin tin over and that worked really well.  Read the reviews -- they are really helpful.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my Wife's bunco party last night and it was a big hit.  I didn't have butter spray, so I melted real butter and brushed it on the tortillas.  Next time I would definitely use spray to speed the process along.  After buttering, I placed 2 cups of sugar and 1/4 cup of cinnamon in a rubbermaid container, added the buttered tortilla, snapped closed and shook it up.  Worked like a charm.  I cut them with a pizza cutter and then baked on an ungreased pan for 8 minutes (350 degrees).  Cool them on a wire rack.  I would also highly recommend making the salsa ahead of time, as it gets better with time.  Fantastic recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My friends loved it~ to avoid having too sour of a salsa...i marinated each fruit separately in sugar a couple of hours before serving and then just omitted the sugar in the end...the fruits still retain their tartness so dont worry about making it too sweet....this allows you to drain all the liquid from the fruits that will otherwise lead to a very mushy salsa...don't mix the fruits until right before serving or else the colors blend together and you end up having gray colored juice from the strawberries and kiwi.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great as a dessert, appetizer, or snack. I have made this several times and I really appreciate the versatility of the recipe. You can substitute or increase certain types of fruit to suit your taste preferences, what is in season, your budget - we've made it with just about every fruit you can imagine. My family likes this when it in't as sweet, so we also cut down on the sugar. Other reviewers have mentioned this - but anytime you add sugar to fruit it will draw out the moisture and make the fruit (especially strawberries) soft. So, if you make it and it seems too firm for your liking, give it an hour in the fridge and the consistency will be different.
Review:

userID:

Display Name:
Amulet707

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to tell you that I'm not much of a cook but I took this to an office potluck and people freaked out! They asked me how to make it, they wanted the recipe, they wanted to know where I 'bought' the chips and were floored when I said I made them. I'm so thrilled with this recipe. What a simple tasty dish with an original flair. I guarantee no one else will have this at your next get-together. I followed the recipe closely but omitted the sugars in the salsa as I thought there would be plenty of sweetness with the cinnamon chips. I forgot to buy butter spray so I brushed on melted butter to each chip before sprinkling the cinnamon and sugar on top. I used a pizza cutter on the tortillas thanks to another reviewers suggestion and that worked perfectly. Based on other suggestions I made sure to take the time to cut everything very small and used strawberry preserves. My only mild complaint was that this took me forever to make. Who knew such a simple recipe would take so long. At first I was like, Oh this is soooo much fun...an hour into it, not so much. lol. Oh and btw, I had a few tortillas left to bake and no more melted butter, so I just sprinkled them with water so that the cinnamon and sugar would adhere and they turned out fantastic. Lastly, I baked a flour tortilla in a oven proof bowl so that I could serve the fruit salsa in it. That was another spectacular suggestion. Thank you for the recipe and thank you all for the wonderful suggestions. Love this site!

text:
This is an easy recipe to make that allows you to be very flexible on the fruits used in the salsa. The cinnamon chips are great! To make them, I stack a few tortillas and cut them with a pizza cutter. Then I spray them with cooking spray and place them in a large bag filled with the cinnamon/sugar mix. Shake the bag to coat the chips, then place them on a cookie sheet for baking. Adults and kids love these!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! Very good! The fruit salsa was so easy to whip up and was incredibly delicious. The cinnamon tortillas were great! The only problem I had with them was the oven temperature and the baking time. After two pans of burnt tortilla chips I finally got the right settings for baking these babies the right way. My oven is true to temp .. it does not run hot - I found the 350 degree temp called for was way too hot. Baking these chips at 325 degrees was perfect. Also the baking time - even at 325 degrees, 8 minutes was sufficient to crisp the chips up. Now that I have the kinks worked out, the recipe is great!

text:
LOVED this!  After reading all of the other reviews and tips, I followed another's reviewers advice on the chips:  I sprayed both sides with the cooking spray, dipped both sides in cinnamon sugar (I made extra cinn sugar than called for), baked at 350 for 10-11 minutes.  They weren't crispy right out of the oven, but they crisped right up in minutes.  The only thing I did differently with the 'salsa' is to squeeze fresh lemon juice over the apples so they wouldn't brown, and it taste wonderful!  It was best after sitting in the fridge overnight.  I think I might cut back on the sugar the next time I make it, but other than that, fantastic!   Thank you for the fabulous recipe!

I really loved this recipe!! I brought it to my friend's bonfire party and everyone really enjoyed it too and were asking for the recipe. I made a few adjustments though. I replaced the raspberries with canned peaches because they're a lot cheaper! I recommend adding a little lemon juice as well to keep the apples from browing.

text:
I really liked this, but like others, I altered it. BUT I'm rating the recipe on the batch I didn't alter. It was soooo sweet!It was a bit too much, but good! The chips were good, and I really liked the pairing. The dish was addicting, even if it was too sweet. The batches I made were with Orange Marmalade, which was good, and apricot preserves. I think I liked the apricot better. I realized I enjoyed the pairing of fruit, and the texture of the small chopped up pieces. So after the first to with the preserves, I just did fruit. Didn't add anything to it. It was soooo much better. So if you don't have a huge sweet tooth, and don't want all the sweetness, just don't add the preserves. Thank you for the recipe!!! I've made it many times, many different ways!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-07-06T15:48:38.407
helpfulCount:
9
userID:
278426
Display Name:
MARY DOMAZ
isPro:
False
followersCount:
38
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
233
favoritesCount:
2017
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a great hit at a recent party. I had many requests for the recipe. I used Fuji apples.I made the salsa in the morning, but did not put the apples in until an hour before serving time. I omitted the sugar. Since I only had a 6 oz. package of raspberries, I added some blueberries which I cut into quarters. I used apricot preserves. I did not find the fruit salsa that time consuming. I know several people mentioned using a food chopper, and although I have one, I was afraid it would make the fruit too mushy. I just chopped with my good knife and it was very fast. 

Now the chips did take time, but I had many good reviews on those also. I made them two days ahead of time and after they cooled completely I put them in a large ziploc bag. I tried buttering and sugaring some on one side and some on two sides. I made some flat and some in the muffin tins. In the end, I preferred the flat ones best that were only buttered and sugared on one side. I suggest that anyone who makes this recipe do the same, and see what you like best. For the chips, I did make my own cinnamon sugar. I used one cup of white sugar and 2 tsp.of cinnamon. For me, it was just right. If you like a very strong cinnamon flavor make sure you add more cinnamon. I did not sprinkle the chips. I dipped each chip into the sugar mixture which I had in a small bowl. I thought it worked well. The pizza cutter idea was great. It made slicing the chips very simple. Enjoy this wonderful recipe!!!
Review:

country:
None
text:
This is a great thing to take to potlucks.  Everyone always loves it!  And its fairly healthy.  Some tips- use a pizza cutter to cut the tortillas or you will spend double the time.  You can use whatever fruit you want, but here's what I do and it has always gotten rave reviews- I use strawberries that are frozen cut up in the sugar and then I do not add sugar or jam- you don't need it when you use these strawberries, raspberries, blackberries and apples.  I use way more than two apples because it really works best when there are more apples than anything else (as far as consistency and flavor) And, I use a veggie chopper- or you'll be cutting forever.

Hints for the chips - use a big ziploc bag and put 1c sugar to 1 tbls cinnamon and DOUBLE the amount of chips!
Hints for the salsa - I used sugar free apricot preserves and added blueberries for the color.  You can make it a day ahead of time, but it takes a long time!  (with all the chopping and making of the chips) 
Turned out great!  It was a huge hit at my mexican potluck!!

text:
My hubby tasted and said "Killer". I don't think fruit choice matters. I used more Kiwi, red apple and granny smith, cantelope,straw berry & maderine orange. I cut out the white sugar and used berry jam. The chips went fast so make extra. I did them like another reviewer. I sprayed both sides while they were whole tortillas. Stacked them on top of each other, sliced wedges with a pizza cutter and tossed them all at once in a zip lock with cin. sugar. Went fast & easy. I also kept the fruit in bigger chunks so it wouldn't get mushy. This is a nice change from the usual fruit bowl.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really loved this recipe! Easy to make and people were raving about it at the party I carried this dish to.
Recommendations I followed:
-Dice the fruit small so each bite gets a good blend of all the fruit.
-Cut & add the (Fuji) apples last to lessen the issue of the apples turning brown.
-Replace the raspberries with frozen peaches
-Do NOT add sugar to the fruit...it is PLENTY sweet without.
-I used peach preserves and it came out great.
-After spraying and cutting up the tortillas, I dredged them in a cinnamon/sugar mixture (1C sugar with 1 1/4t cinnamon for 2 packs of tortillas) and baked them. No need to spray again.
-Dress with a dollop of Cool Whip for and *extra* special treat.

text:
This was wonderful! I used 1 large Gala apple, 2 kiwi and 1 pint of strawberries .... mixed the preserves (I used strawberry) with  1 tablespoon white sugar and the juice of half an orange. Mixed it with the fruit and made severel batches of the "chips". My daughter and her friends licked the bowl clean! Though it took some time to dice all the fruit, it was so worth it. I made things easier with the chips by buying the taco size, cutting in fourths and spraying/sugaring only one side. Baked for 9 minutes and they were perfect! A hit with adults and teens .... a keeper for my family! Thanks for the awesome (and healthy) recipe!

text:
FANTASTIC.  I have shared this recipe with countless friends who have loved it and make it all the time themselves.  To cut cost, I sometimes buy blueberries and raspberries that I squish down to add to the mix- don't thing you would want to go frozen on any of the other ingredients though, the crunch of the fresh fruit is part of its overall appeal.  I am not big on sugar, so i usually just sprinkle about a tablespoon of white sugar on, and omit the brown sugar and preserves.  I like the contrast of the tart fresh fruit and slightly sweet cinnamon chips.  Ann, thank you so much!

text:
I have made this twice for office pot-luck meals. Both times it was gone in 2 hours. They raved over it! I use a lot more fruit then it calls for (because I was feeding so many people) and changed fruit each time I made it. I think any fruit in season is fine to use. Once I accidentally bought corn tortillas, I won't ever do that again! Make sure to use flour tortillas as the recipe calls for. Also I used the 6 inch tortillas and cut them in quarters. They make the perfect size chip.

country:
None
text:
Wow, this totally lived up to it's reputation, amazingly delicious! I used green grapes instead of the kiwis, and also added blueberries. The key is to chop the fruit into small, similar sized pieces. The raspberries I had were large so I sliced them in  half. I chose apple jelly since that was already open, heated it to liquify and then stirred in about a tsp of the cinnamon sugar blend from the chips. I added none of the other sugars. I made the chips the way the most helpful reviewer suggested and it worked perfectly. I used a mix of regular flour and whole wheat tortillas and that made a very pretty presentation in the basket next to the salsa. Both the kids and adults enjoyed this!

text:
We LOVED this!!!...both the salsa and the chips!  I almost left out the raspberries due to cost, but they-with the combination of the other fruits as listed in the recipe- really make this special!  I chopped up the fruit fairly well, so that it actually resembled the texture of salsa rather than a fruit salad.  I needed to keep the apples from turning (I used Fuji), so I did very lightly sprinkle fresh lime juice on them before adding to the salsa.  The addition of that hint of tangy lime helped tone down the sweetness and really perked up the flavor of the salsa! (I omitted the white sugar, but did use the brown, and used reduced sugar strawberry preserves.)

What a fantastic idea! I took this to a work potluck and it was huge success. The best part was the chips-I cut the tortillas into triangles, sprayed with butter-flavored cooking spray, shook to coat in a gallon-sized storage bag of cinnamon and sugar, and then baked. Wonderful! For the salsa, I used frozen blackberries, diced kiwi, diced apples, diced strawberries, and diced frozen peaches-at the last minute I added diced bananas. This doesn't stay fresh and pretty too long so I made it very early in the morning and it was perfect at lunchtime.

950377
Display Name:
Baker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this recipe 5 stars even though I've tweaked it to my personal preference after making it several times.  For fruit I use kiwis, Altulfo mangoes, strawberries and blackberries.  This variety gives a great colour presentation.  I don't like it with the apples because of their crunchy texture...the soft fruit goes better with the crunchy chips.  I leave out the sugar and use seedless red raspberry jam for the preserves.  I chop up the fruit in advance, then drain any juice before adding the jam.  Spray both sides of the tortilla then use a pizza cutter to cut them into pieces.  Then I shake one cut-up tortilla at a time in a ziploc bag filled with the cinnamon sugar (2 cups sugar with 3-4 tbsp cinnamon).  To get a nice scoop shape, I put 1-2 tortilla pieces in muffin cups, but if you're short on time, placing them on a tray means you can bake more all at once!  Bake for about 9 minutes then loosen with a spatula or remove immediately from the tray otherwise they stick.   I always make the chips a day in advance as I find they are crunchier and taste better.  My guests have all raved about this recipe!

text:
Holy cow!! This stuff should come with a warning because it's a little like crack. I made this for the first time about 2 months ago for a get together, and have since made it 5 more times, not for a get together mind you, but for my boyfriend and I because we are addicts!! I didn't change anything about the salsa but used orange marmalade for the preserves. The chips are where I made some changes and I think this is the only way to make these babies! I melted butter and coated the tortilla wedges with it, then put them in a big ziplock baggie filled with cinnamon and sugar and shook like crazy, my chips were coated with butter and sugar! Then I baked for like 15 - 17 minutes, because  we like them with a little crunch. Anyway, my boyfriend and I have decided this is probably what they serve in heaven. ;-)P.S. I wouldn't change a thing about the salsa. I would not omit the sugars because we didn't think this was too sweet at all. I also don't know if I would mess with different fruits, why mess with perfection?! And I definitely wouldn't use frozen fruit - yuck!! Also, I did my sugar and preserves first, then the raspberries and strawberries, then the kiwis and apples. I threw the apples in as soon as I chopped and didn't have a problem with browning. I didn't use red delicious apples because I can't stand their grainy, mushy texture. I think I used pink ladys.

text:
This was heavenly.  My guests just loved it.  The best part is that my kids love it as well!  Like others, I didn't feel it was necessary to add sugar.  I simply used Raspberry preserves.  I made sure to dip the apples in lemon juice to avoid browning.  The cinnamon chips were a hit as well.  I did not coat the tortillas with cooking spray (yuck!).  I brushed them lightly with butter and then coatd them with the cinnamon/sugar by putting them in a ziploc bag and shaking them.  I also turned the chips half-way through baking (which actually took 12-15 minutes for me).  If I'm short on time I might use the Stacy's cinnamon chips instead.  This would be good on ice cream or angel food cake as well.

text:
Love this recipe!  I didn't add any sugar OR preserves to the fruit salsa.  It was perfect without it.  I added blueberries and may add some crushed pineapple the next time.  I followed someone's suggestion and put the sprayed tortillas in a bag with cinnamon sugar and shook it up.  You may need to put some more sugar on after you place them on the baking sheet.  Do NOT overlap the chips or they won't bake well.  They do continue to cook after removing them from the oven.  Have fun!

text:
I love this recipe (along with everyone at the Super Bowl party)! Instead of the various fruits, I thawed a bag of frozen berry mix and a bag of red raspberries. I cut up the fruit and added the sugars and preserves (again red raspberries), then refrigerated. Very berry!! 

But the biggest hit of all were the torilla chips. A little girl at the Super Bowl party ate them by the handful! I used regular (not butter) Pam spray and sprayed both sides of the tortilla, then I cut each into about 12 slices. Then I dredged each slice of tortilla through the cinnamon sugar mixture (1 cup sugar and 1 t. cinnamon) and baked for about 6 minutes each in a muffin tin. That was a suggestion to create a "scooped" tortilla chip. 

Thanks for the great recipe, Ann!!

city:

country:

text:
Have made this recipe many times and each time it was a great hit, no left over.   I think I have it to perfection.  I usually cut up the fruits (apples, kiwis, peach, plum, raspberry strawberries, pineapple - crushed) the night before, combine all except strawberries. Also make cinnamon chips night before.  Lightly spray both sides tortillas with cooking spray then sprinkle with cinnamon sugar using shaker (so quick & easy), layer tortillas on top of each other, cut in half, cut each half in half then in half.  Mix sugar and preserves (great with a variety of two or three preserves/marmalade) then only mix into fruits just before serving.  Wont stay long enough for it to get runny. Excellent appetizer for Valentine's dinner/Mother's Day or any occasion.  You will not be disappointed!

Wow can I give this 6 stars!!! Awesome recipe! I made three  small changes. I used two tablespoons of honey in place of all the sugar, 5 grain tortillas and chopped the fruit a lot smaller that the fruit in the picture. I split the recipe into two and took it to two cookouts. For the first cookout I served it in a tortilla bowl that I made while I was chopping the fruit. I sprayed the tortilla with the cooking spray and pushed into the bottom of a bowl so it ruffled and backed at 350 for 15 mins. Filled it with the fruit right befor I left the house. The second house I served it in a bowl I made from the bottom half of a pineapple covered it with the top of the pineapple. Both were a beautiful presentation! Had to tell everyone how I made the Salsa and Chips so many times I should have had it typed out and ready when people asked. Everyone loved the chips by them self, could never make to many. Loved the salsa too but when you put them together it was pure BLISS!!! Everyone talked about how you could eat this as an appetizer, dessert or even for breakfest. I will be making this alot!!!

text:
I love this recipe!!! I used an egg slicer for some of the prep work and it did not take long at all to make. The grocery store was out of raspberries so i substituted them with blueberries. I used a blackberry jam and cut it back from 3 tablespoons to 2. I did not add any sugar and I thought that it was sweet enough. I bought cinnamon graham crackers instead of making them. The next time that I make this, I am going to add one more kiwi to the mix. I was surprised how much it made, just remember when using all of these fresh fruits, the shelf life is very short. The next day things were a little soggy....

Display Name:
METSgal31

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/571393.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this appetizer at a Superbowl party as a healthier alternative to the wings, fried food, chips & dip that crowded the rest of the table. To my surprise, the fruit salsa went the fastest! My guests loved it! I fancied it up a bit by putting the fruit in a hollowed out pineapple half. It not only tasted great- it looked nice too! There are lots of variations you can use with this recipe, but I find harder tropical fruits that are easy to chop into small bits work the best (Mango, pineapple, strawberries, kiwi, guava, papaya etc...) Apples go brown too quickly, bananas are too mushy and berries are too hard to chop into small bits. I wanted it to be finely chopped to make it easier to pick up with the yummy cinnamon chips.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this attending a dinner party. The theme was Summertime Blues and I chose this one and it was perfect! I didn't have some of the fruits and wanted to use the ones I have before they go bad, so I used frozen blackberries diced, pomegranates, any kind of apple, and instead of the preserves I used some leftover cranberry sauce with raspberries. I didn't add the brown sugar and not too much of the white sugar since the cranberry sauce and the fruit was already sweet enough. I ran out of butter spray, so I did like a dipping method and dipped the tortilla in butter mixed with sugar and cinnamon and baked it as the recipe called for. It was a huge hit! Make extra chips though... they're good even without the salsa. A friend of mine used her salsa on some grilled chicken. Others were just spooning it onto their plates and eating it as a sauce. Perfect for after Turkey Day!

This was really yummy.  I made it for an all day scrap and I received rave reviews.  I left the sugar out of the fruit.  I think this could be made with any seasonal fruit.  I added blueberries and peaches.  You will not be disappointed if you try this one!  Add on:  I made this again and I put the salsa in a tupperware container that had a strainer at the bottom.  This worked out great because all of the juice from the fruit went to the bottom, and the fruit was kept out of the juices.  I think the container is supposed to be for berries.

text:
DELICIOUS!! I followed the numerous reviews and made the following changes...so glad I did! 1) use frozen peaches instead of raspberries 2) omit the sugar 3) use orange marmalade for the fruit preserve 4) use fugi apples instead of golden delicious - add last  For the tortillas: again I followed the reviews and so glad I did: 1) spray both sides with pam 2) sprinkle both sides with cinn/sugar mix 3) stack 4 high and cut with pizza cutter  I had to flip my tortillas when I cooked them so both sides were crisp (7-8 min on one side and ~5 min on the other side)  one of my all time favorite recipes so far on this site!!!!!

country:

text:
Oh my!  Amazing!  The store I went to was out of raspberries, so I skipped those.  I used strawberry all fruit preserves.  I wanted to make this healthier, so I used baking splenda instead of sugar and splenda brown sugar blend instead of brown sugar.  I used whole wheat tortillas.  I was afraid that they wouldn't work out too well, but they were awesome.  I also used splenda for the cinnamon sugar on the tortillas.  I combined 1/4 cup splenda with 4 teaspoons of cinnamon and sifted it over the tortillas.  I sprayed both sides of the tortillas with the butter flavor Pam, stacked them and cut into wedges with a pizza cutter.  Then I sifted on the cinn sugar and sprayed again.  They turned out perfect at about 10 minutes.  This was amazing!  One more thing. . . I saw that people were saying that this recipe takes too long.  I bought a Vidalia Chopper at Bed Bath and Beyond and it is awesome!  It makes preparing this recipe a snap!  I use it with so many things, guacamole, salsa, anything you need to chop!  I highly recommend it for this recipe.

text:
I doubled this recipe and took it to a party of 25 people, and it was pretty much all gone by the end of the night. We used blueberries, strawberries and kiwi, and pineapple (not canned). My recommendation -- bake the chips longer, we did about 13 minutes, so the were light golden browm, not tough but crispy -- the butter spray worked prefectly.  Also, don't skip the jam --  we used strawberry and it helps to hold the salsa together.   No sugar is needed in the salsa.  I also drained it before I served it, then gave it a good stir.

text:
OOOHHHH MMMMYYY!!!  What a fabulous little recipe.  I used kiwi, apple, strawberry, blueberry, grapes and apricot preserve.  I skipped the sugar and it was plenty plenty sweet from the fruits.  I made ahead of time by a couple of hours and it did have a nice juice that formed on the bottom of the bowl that I just stirred up and dunked away- with those delicious chips.
I only needed 1 cup sugar and 1 tbsp of cinnamon and it coated all my chips plenty.  I followed suit and put all chips in a big tupperware with sugar and cinnamon and mixed around.  I baked some on a baking sheet and some in mini muffin tins and I like the muffin tins ones the most..you really can get a good scoop of the fruit with the juice in them.  Can't wait to make for a party to impress.

I have made this twice now in the last week.  It is amazing!  I made it exactly by the recipe the first time and it was awesome. text:
Very easy to prepare, however, I prepared the fruit salsa 6+ hours before serving and found that the kiwi had broken down and the salsa had become way too soupy with juice from the fruit. The chips were very good but we all found it too difficult to scoop the salsa onto the chips. We resorted to using a spoon to spoon it on top. All in all it tasted fresh and sweet. Added plus is that you can prpare it using Splenda sweetener and fat free tortillas making this a wonderfully low calorie, low fat treat! :) Great as dessert! Alternative to chips-make same way but form the whole tortilla into a dish shape using an oven proof bowl. Spoon fruit into cinnamon sugar tortilla dish and top with a dollop of Cool Whip!:)

This was excellent and well recieved.  I gave it 4 stars because I made a sample with preserves and thought it overwhelmed the overall taste of the dish.  I used 1/2 the sugar and used all lt. brown sugar.  I also left out the kiwi.  People loved it!  The chips are great and can be baked at a higher temp for a shorter amount of time.  I also used Splenda sugar substitute and cinnamon sugar for a low cal alternative - Awesome!  Couldn't tell the difference.  By the way I used butter on the chips and Spray Pam. The Pam chips turned out much lighter tasting - which was preferrable for me!  Enjoy it - it's great at parties.  The suggested serving is right on.  I made a double batch for 13 people and it was way to much.

text:
I made this for a neighborhood block party last night, and was asked for the recipe many times.  Instead of using the raspberries, which are very expensive in Minnesota this time of year, I used a 5 oz. bag of dried cranberries, cherries and blueberries.  The juice from the fruit rehydrated the dried fruit, making the salsa less runny.  Also the cranberries added a nice tartness to the sweetness of the salsa.  An excellent appetizer!

Display Name:
KRANEY
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, was this great!!  I used 4 kiwis, 2 fuji apples sprinkled with fresh lemon juice to keep them from browning, 1 cup diced frozen peaches, 1 lb. strawberries and NO added sugar.  I used 3 Tbl. raspberry preserves (loved the flavor!), and ended up needing a little more juice to it all (probably because of the additional kiwis), so I added 1 Tbl. fresh orange juice.  Perfect!  Spraying the fronts AND backs of the tortillas, then dredging in a mixture of 1 cup sugar + 1 Tbl. cinnamon was perfect!  Don't let the chips overlap, or they will be gooey in that overlapped spot.  I also tried whole wheat tortillas and they were great!  I baked them 9 minutes on a cookie sheet with foil.  Note that if after a couple of days the chips become stale, just pop them back in the oven at 350 for 5 minutes.  Taste as good as when you initially made them!  Thanks for the recipe!

Rating:

userID:
9346686
Display Name:
youharts
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
22
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried a different fruit combo: braeburn apples, strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, fresh pineapple, and peaches. Really didn't need to add any sweetener, but added 1 TBSP sugar just to make more liquid while it sits. 

I used spray Parkay for the chips, but would use butter flavored cooking spray instead- the spray butter allowed for too much cinnamon/sugar mixture to stay on the chips. I paired 2 tortillas, cut them in half, placed the halves together, then cut the half-circle shapes into 4 triangles. A scissors worked great. Then I laid the pieces on a plate, sprayed one side, flipped them & sprayed the other side. I mixed the cinnamon & sugar in a gallon zip-close bag, placed 4 traingles at a time in the bag & shook to coat. Baked them 10-12 minutes per batch at 400. 
Super easy!! The whole family loved it!!

text:
Everyone loved this!  I added extra fruit - 3 kiwis, 12 ounces raspberries, 3 apples (2 braeburn and 1 granny smith) and I had some frozen peaches to use up so I chopped up some of those also.  I only had 1 lb of strawberries but wish I had more, they were surprisingly good for this time of the year!  I kept the jam amount the same and just sprinkled some brown sugar over the top.  I also tossed my apples with lemon juice, just in case, I didnt want them browning up at all.  The tortilla chips with cinnamon and sugar were wonderful also!  I can't wait to make this again and try some different fruit combo's.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe for years and love it.  I too will cut the sugar and preserves but I think it is better if you use rasberry preserves.  I have used the egg cutter to cut the strawberries as well.  If you are in a big hurry and the texture isn't as important to you--you can use a food proccesor as well.  I prefer fresh strawberries but for blackberries and raspberries I have used frozen and it didn't seem to alter the recipes too much. This is a healthy recipe for an after school snack for kids.  I am diabetic and so I will add cinnamon as well---but watch it if your diabetic--its is soo good, its easy to get too many carbs as there is more fruit than it seems because it is cut up and thus concentrated.

Followed the fruit part exactly and was so good!  For the tortillas, I melted butter and brushed on cut tortillas and sprinkled with the cinnamon sugar. text:
Oh my this is good! Fresh and Fruity Flavor with crunch and a bit of sweetness! I have made this and severed it with the cinnamon chips, as topping on a plain sponge cake, as well as just by it self as a fruit side dish in the summer. I added a bit more brown sugar and white sugar to make it just a bit sweeter. 1 tsp each. The best part of this is the great unusual taste combination. Not your typical fruit combination, as well as the pretty color it adds to your dinner table or party. I have made this over and over again because it is always requested at family gatherings. My kids love it!

text:
Took this to a friends house last night most everyone enjoyed it.  I made the sugar/brw sugar pres. mixer and tasted it before I put on friut.  It was to sweet for my taste so only sprinkled a few teaspoons on the fruit and let it sit in fridge for several hours and mixed well.  I diced everything up but the raspberries in small pieces.  And it took forver to get the torillas crispy, I had to bake both sides.  Next time I will just fry the torillas and shake in bag with cinnom. and sugar, may not be healthier but faster and easier.  I will make this again.

it was super easy to make, but I found that it was far too sweet. I would definitely leave out the white sugar and cut the amount of preserves in half. Instead of tortilla chips, I made cinnamon pita chips. I followed the same directions as the tortilla chips but cut the pita bread so that there is the top and the bottom of the piece and cut each side in fourths and then the fourths in half (eighths), sprayed with butter flavored cooking spray and sprinkled cinnamon sugar on them, and then sprayed them again

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fun desert to play around with. I especially love the cinnamon chips. I took the advice of a review and sprayed butter flavored Pam on the front and back of each tortilla, then poured the sugar/cinnamon mixture over. I also prefer to cut them into strips than wedges (just easier to eat without the chips being so wide). Also, please whatever you do, cut the sugar. I am a sugar lover, and decided to make the recipe with the sugar, but it was way toooooo sweet. I also didn't use any preserves because I didn't have any, it still tasted great. But be warned, it doesn't last well. Make it when you plan on using it. All in all, this is a great recipe. I am sure I will be using it many more times.

One note, instead of spraying with butter flavor cooking spray, we brushed the tortillas's with butter and then sprinkled on the cinnamon sugar. text:
This was a huge hit at my bbq tonight! The chips were fantastic! HOWEVER, make sure you bake the chips long enough or else it will be really tough. If the chips seem tough or hard to chew, just put them back in the oven for 5-10 minutes. I ended up baking my chips for about 20 minutes for each batch. I used a pizza cutter for the chips and it worked out great!! I also added nectarines and blueberries for color. I think next time i'll used a different kind of apple because the golden delicious apples were a tad sour. A lot of water juice/liquid comes out of this dip from the sugars so I just poured some of the juice out so it wouldn't be so soupy. I also didn't put any brown sugar because other reviewers said it was too sweet. Anyways, awesome summer snack! Thanks so much!!

I made this for dessert at a BBQ we had.  Everyone loved it.  The Cinnamon Chips were great & this whole dish was easy to prepare.  

I used Strawberries, Raspberries, Gala Apple and a Red Pear. I used a Mixed Berry jam and the results were great!! I cut the fruit into small squares so it would be easy to scoop with the chips. 

There is no need for measurements really I could make this and adjust it to the quantity I want and tailor the fruit to our likes or dislikes.  I will be making this for a long time and will be my go to in a pinch.

userID:
6530719
Display Name:
Suzyduzy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

madeRecipesCount:
7

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super duper scrumptious! Perfect for a beach party I went to today & everyone loooved it! I made a ton of chips per the other reviews & glad I did as people did munch on those alone. 
I substituted mango for rasberries because I love mango & thought some orange would be a nice addition. Also added about a 1/2 cup of blueberries for color. It was very pretty. 
I suspect it depends on the fruit you're using & its level of ripeness but I added absolutely no sugar at all. All of my fruit was very ripe. The mango in particular added more than enough sweetness that I almost didn't even add the preserves either. 
I did end up using apricot preserves which worked very well but think it would have been excellent without it too. If your fruit is ripe the salsa will be sweet, really that's it. 
I tripled the recipe so, out of necessity, used a food processor. I pulsed each fruit separately being careful not to over process them into a mush then tossed them together. Turned out to be perfect! Not only did it speed up the process immensely but also chopped up everything to an ideal size giving it a real chunky salsa appearance (rather than a fruit salad) & making it easy to scoop up with the chips which would have been difficult with larger pieces.
Peeled, chopped & added the apples (Fuji) last & they never browned despite being made the day before & sitting in the sun for 5 hours. 
Wonderful recipe! I will be making this weekly to have around the house for snacks. Thank you!!! Ingenious!

country:
None
text:
Everyone at my family get togethers LOVES this dish now!  Although I think there is one thing that is essential (at least from my experience) that is an absolute dealbreaker here, and that is the texture of the fruit.  The first time I made this dish, I sliced up the fruit into small chunks with a knife.  Everyone liked it, but it wasn't a huge hit.  The second time, I used a blade chopper and chopped the pieces up much finer like actual salsa (in my picture).  This time everyone LOVED the dish, and it was completely gone.  It seems like the smaller the chunks the better, but without it being soupy.  I also used fuji apples, boysenberry preserves, and added a small amount of blueberries!

text:
I made a Newfoundland version of this recipe. I combine blueberries, partridgeberries and bake apples, added sugar (not much - I wanted to taste the bite of the partridgeberries), and used NF-picked cranberry sauce as my preserve. Fresh, tarte, and FULL of flavor. Loved it.
And to top it off, I opened a bottle of "Moose Juice", a local wine made in Twillingate, NL. It is a wine made from partridgeberries and blueberries, and was so smooth and just the right sweetness to go with this. 
I cheated and bought the cinnamon chips, but won't do that again. Many were cracked too small to use. I will use this recipe (with the hints for speeding up the process) next time.
Thanks for the inspiration! I will make this again soon.

text:
We loved it!  It's  nice recipe to add to as well.  I added more kiwis, tossed in some blueberries for color, and a pear just because I had one sitting there looking at me.  
For the chips, I tried what some other reviewers suggested, spraying both sides of the tortillas and dredging them in the cinnamon/sugar, but those came out a little sticky and chewy.  Just doing one side came out perfect and crispy.
All in all, a great recipe, perfect for kids, crowds, or anyone!

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a keeper!  A refreshing change from the usual savory salsa.  Admittedly, a bit time consuming to make.  I've made it twice already.  Both kids and adults really enjoyed it.  You don't have to use all the cinnamon sugar mix.  I used a mix of white and whole wheat tortillas.  I sprayed and sugared both sides of the tortilla, stacked them and used a pizza cutter to cut it into 12 wedges.  For the salsa I used two types of apples, 1 lb of strawberries and 2 mangoes.  I omitted the 2Tbsps of white sugar; it was sweet enough with 1Tbsp brown sugar and 3Tbsp of strawberry freezer jam.  I made a bowl for the salsa out of one tortilla (spray both sides of tortilla and gently press into oven proof bowl.  Bake at 350 degrees for about 10 minutes until crispy) as one reviewer suggested.  Even the tortilla bowl was good to eat (all that was left)!  I will definitely make this again and try multigrain tortillas next time.

text:
Wow!  This is a great recipe! I only made 1 real change. I lessened the sugar by 1T.  (Used 1 1/2T white, 1/2T brown).  I found the chips to be easiest to make by spraying the front of one tortilla at a time with the butter spray, dredging them in a bowl of the cinnamon sugar, placing them on a cookie sheet and spritzing them with butter spray again.  Other reviewers suggested spraying and coating both sides of the tortillas but that turned into a disaster for me!

Display Name:
Mist

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Absolutely delish!!  Made this twice within the last two weeks and have had to give the recipe to about ten people.  Used fresh strawberries, kiwis, apples, and 12 oz. frozen blueberries instead of the raspberries and it held together really well without getting soggy.  Used apricot preserves.  The first time I made it, I added the apples just before serving because I thought they would turn brown,,,but when we had leftovers, two days later, the apples were still fresh and crisp.  The second time I made it I went ahead and added the apples right away and they did not turn brown and they stayed crisp (I refrigerated the apples before adding). The chips were easy to make:  1) Spray several tortillas on both sides with cooking spray 2) Stack and cut with pizza cutter  3) Toss the wedges into a 9x13" pan filled with cinnamon sugar  4) Bake on ungreased cookie sheet for about 9 minutes.  Cool on wire rack Note:  If adults only will be devouring this, you can sneak in a sprinkling of Grand Marnier if desired!!  Yummm

text:
Big hit with family and friends.  This recipe is very adaptable to your tastes in fruit.  I used all fresh fruit - strawberries, kiwis (which add nice color), applies, raspberries, and mango.  For the jam, I used apricot preserves.  I did not add the sugar and don't think it is needed.  A small dice on the fruit works best.  Kept the raspberries whole.   Made a double batch of the chips and still had some salsa left.  Sprayed the tortillas with butter flavored spray on both sides, stacked 4 or 5 together and cut in wedges.  Dredged in a pie plate of my own cinnamon sugar mix.   Baked for about 10 minutes.

text:
AMAZING!  A few subs--I used I can't believe it's not butter spray on the tortillas and then dredged them (twice) in the cinnamon sugar mix.  I baked for about 10 minutes (first batch), 9 on the second and 7 on the third (as the batches got smaller so did the cooking time).  I then dusted the freshly baked chips with generous sprinkle of the cinnamon sugar mixture!  For the fruit I used strawberries, kiwi, papaya, and fuji apples with peach preserves.  People fought over the leftovers to take home!  I did use some of the leftover sauce to saute some shrimp and it was an incredible flavor.  Tons of uses for the salsa...on pound cake, in a crepe, on pancakes, the list is endless!   I already have requests to make it again!

text:
I'm going to re-review this. I made this once for a party and it was great. I'm making it again for Easter but I wanted to comment a little further. First, to all the reviewers who didn't like this because it was too liquidy: This is a SALSA not a salad so expect it to be juicy. I don't think I have every had a salsa that isn't really juicy. If you want a fruit salad use a different recipe because this isn't what you're looking for. But, if you want a salsa but just want it a little LESS juicy (this will also make it a little less sweet for those who complained that it was too sweet), try 1) using harder tart apples like you would for an apple pie 2) use kiwis that aren't all the way ripe so they are harder and less juicy (since you add the sugar sauce anyway you won't notice the tartness) and 3) before adding the sugar/preserve sauce, put all the chopped fruit in a salad spinner and spin some of the juices out. 4) toss in the raspberries at the end so they don't mush up when you toss in the sugar/preserve mixture.  This will make the salsa a little more chunky and less juicy. But like I said, its salsa, so expect it to be juicy. This is a really awesome recipe if you don't mind all the time consuming chopping.  You really do have to use fresh fruit, not frozen. I used apple flavored jelly for the preserves. Fantastic. I could do without the cinnamon chips personally. They aren't that bad but you can buy better ones at the grocery store. Too much work and they are kind of bor

text:
This was great!  Time saving tip:  put your cinnamon/sugar in a galon zip-lock bag. spray the tortilla's, cut into chips and then put them in your cinnamon/sugar bag and shake.  They will evenly coat and taste great.  I baked mine for 8 minutes and they were perfect!  I had about three batches. I also drained the extra fruit juice off the salsa before  serving. It can be soupy otherwise.  My girlfriends loved this...super easy and wonderful!

I have to be honest.... I was expecting something amazing based on reviews but I thought this recipe was just "ok". Maybe it's just me though. Some tips... Make the day before. The apples don't turn brown and the flavor melds together better after sitting. My biggest disappointment was the chips. I made them according to the directions however I burnt the first 2 batches. Mine were done after only 5 minutes on the middle rack. Also.. load on the cinnamon/sugar mix. The ones that were lightly sugared taste kinda gross. GOOD LUCK to others. Again, it wasn't aweful, just time consuming for the finished result.

userID:

Display Name:
Miz

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent.. the hit of the picnic! Here's what I did differently - I used 1 Fuji apple (rubbed with lemon juice so it wouldnt brown) 1 pear, 1 peach, 1 nectarine, 2 kiwi, about a half cup of pineapple, 1 pint each of strawberries and blueberries... all fresh. I added NO sugar, and used 2 teaspoons of raspberry preserves. I diced the strawberries, kiwi, and pineapple the night before.. keeping them in separate containers, of course. I did not use a food chopper if you dice the fruit by hand it will help to avoid a mushy salsa. I made the chips the night before, to save time. For the chips - i used 2 bags of 10 inch tortillas. From that I got 2 big Hefty Zip Lock bags full. I did the butter cooking spray and cinnamon sugar on each side, and cut them with a pizza cutter. I did some flat on a cookie sheet, and some in mini muffin pans.. the cookie sheets are the way to go if you wanna save on time - the muffin pan chips were fun for the scoopable effect. I baked them at 350 for about 10 minutes and then let them cool on the hot cookie sheet which left them with a nice crispness. The chips were a HUGE hit. Everyone raved about them. Yes - this recipe is time consuming. Be prepared for that from the start.It is worth the effort. My father-in-law even asked me for the recipe. He has NEVER asked me for a recipe in 15 years. This recipe is that good. He wasnt the only one - everyone wanted details. It is definitely a keeper... and will become a July 4th staple at our picnics.

text:
Absolutely wonderful!  The great reviews are true.  So simple yet elegant, even.  I did a pre-party tryout last nite. Wow!  I didn't sprinkle enough sugar on chips, though.  Go ahead, be heavy handed.  There is plenty of liquid even though it doesn't seem like there will be at first.  So, don't overdo the "sauce."  I kept the sugar stictly according to the recipe and while we liked it that way, you could certainly cut it.  It tasted excellent just a half hour later and I used out of season strawberries, kiwi, granny smiths, and frozen peaches with peach preserves.  It is at its prettiest the same day but still looks and tastes really good the next.  I also tried making some chips in baby muffin cups to get the scoop effect but they were more of a hassle than worth it.  I say eat over a napkin, or scoop a bit onto a cocktail plate and enjoy!

text:
This recipe is extremely versatile and you can't go wrong even if you modify it. I cut my fruit very small for this recipe and I think that's a key component to enjoy it. It's easier to "scoop" onto pita chips. I use pretty much any fruit I have in the house and I've made it with as few as three different fruits but no more than five different fruits. I've used cantaloupe (that's a must for me in this recipe), strawberries, and different kinds of apples. You absolutely must try it.

text:
I read many reviews to anticipate what others felt was problematic before trying the recipe. What stood out in the reviews is that not one (that I read, because I certainly didn't read thousands!) mentioned using FRUIT FRESH to keep the fruits from browning!! I've used it for over 25 years to keep (especially) apples from browning! You don't need much and it's fool-proof! It had to be for ME to get it right!

text:
I used white fleshed nectarines instead of apples for a memorial day picnic (I thought it was more summery than an apple, which I associate with fall) and I also didn't add a lick of suger, just a teaspoon of homemade raspberry preserves and the result was fantastic! For the chips I used a homemade spiced sugar that had vanilla sugar (made by storing a vanilla bean in a small container of sugar), cardamom, cinnamon and nutmeg. Although regular cinnamon sugar would have been fine, I had this on hand so I used it. So amazing that even though I made loads, they were gone before the salsa was!

Excellent, even in the dead of winter (when the fruit is not really good)!  I used raspberry preserves, and threw in the 1/2 c. or so of blueberries that I needed to use. This was a perfect nosh for Christmas Night, bright, fresh, light, a little sumpin-sumpin after the earlier feasting.  Thanks for the recipe!

city:
