region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great! I needed something for a work Halloween potluck. I used this, omitted the raspberries used a bag of frozen peaches and I omitted the added sugars.  I also used orange marmalade - great taste like a small hint of orange, not overpowering.  It was a hit with the cinnamon tortilla chips! I didn't have any butter cooking spray, only vegetable - didn't chance it. I melted Country Crock in the microwave, used the bbq brush and brushed the tortillas w/ melted country crock first. Then, I cut them in fours w/ pizza cutter. I used 1 cup of sugar/ 1 1/2 tbs cinnamon. - PERFECTION!!! No one in the office has ever tasted anything so delicious. There was none left, everyone was taking some home.

I didn't add any extra sugar to the salsa and found it to still be delicious! I had also never made tortilla chips before and found that i had to cook them much longer (12-15 minutes) than the recipe stated-- until they turned golden brown. Otherwise they became very tough and chewy (though still delicious) instead of crunchy.

text:
Great recipe. Whole family loved it especially my four year old.  One tip to those who are worried about brown apple slices, Squeeze some lemon juice on them. It doesn't affect the taste and keeps them from browning for a few hours.  You can also dunk them in some salt water solution, this also works well and lasts longer than the lemon juice.

text:
This is actually like 4 1/2 stars (followed the recipe exactly)... the only hints that I have to give are 1) make the chips the same day of the event - my got a little chewy the next day.  2) It makes A LOT of "salsa" - have a big group or be prepared for leftovers.  3) The salsa tends to get juicy over time - if you don't care for juice you'll need to drain it off.

userID:
710709
Display Name:
Carol Long
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a superbowl party.  I am pregnant and craving fruit and thought there probably wouldn't be any at a superbowl party so I made this more for myself than the guests. I also made spinach dip in hawaiian bread. This was such a huge success that I barely ate any. Matter of fact, it was the first thing eaten completely even though we had 7 dips, 3 main dishes, and lots of desert. I was the only one without leftovers and I doubled the recipe!

Here are my tips for making this dish. I cut up all the fruit and placed them in a colander to drain while cutting. The apples I placed in a ziploc bag with a squeeze of lemon juice and less than a tsp. of sugar to keep them from browning. I used orange marmalade and only 1 tbsp. of white sugar and 1 tbsp of brown. It was sweet enough and you could really taste the fruit. The fruit I used was fresh pineapple, granny smith and red delicious apples, strawberries, kiwi, and nectarines. Well worth the energy and time spent cutting fruit.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I make this all the time - everyone asks for it.  I chop my fruit very fine and mix it together and then let it strain for at least an hour or the salsa is juicy.  I occasionaly add a finely minced jalapeno pepper for a sweet and hot contrast.  We usually use butter spray and spray a staff at a time of tortillas.  Cut the up into wedges with a pizza cutter and then shake them in a Ziploc bag with the cinnamon sugar, then we bake them in a muffin or a mini-muffin tin to create a "Scoop" chip.  I like them crispy so I cook mine longer too.  Love these!

It is amazing how all these simple ingredients create such an impressive dish. Use whatever fruits that are in season. Both kids & adults loved it. Will make over and over!

text:
Terrific!  1300+ reviewers can't be wrong.  A forgiving recipe - just use what fruit you have since I don't think you can mess this up.  It does get soupy - doesn't the sugar bring out the juice in the strawberries?  For that reason I drained the salsa before serving, but it still made MORE juice while it was in the serving bowl.  Next time I'll try omitting the sugar and just using the preserves.  Also used bagged Cinnamon Sugar pita chips from Trader Joe's which were yummy and saved lots of time.  UPDATE:  I had a package of whole wheat flour tortillas to use up so I tried them for the chips.  I was able to mix 1/2 white sugar with 2 1/2 T cinnamon which made plenty of cinnamon sugar mix to generously cover eight 8" tortillas.  An easy enough project that my 3 yr old was able to "help" and the chips turned out pretty good too.

text:
If I could give this 10 stars, I would!  This is an original, tasty, and refreshing summer recipe that has everyone flipping out!  I have taken it to numerous barbecues, picnics, and other parties and have watched it disappear.  A co-worker of mine ate about 8 servings of it one afternoon...it's THAT good.  It is worth it to take the time to make the cinnamon chips...they actually stay fresh for quite awhile in an airtight container, so you could make a large batch for multiple occasions.  Make sure you buy thin tortillas (Pinata brand in the refrigerated case are my favorite) so the chips are nice and crispy.  Dicing all the fruit to about the same size is also worth the extra time...it makes it easier to eat.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this fruit salsa for a couple of years now.  The only difference is that I always switch up the types of fruit.  I made it last week for a work pot-luck lunch and used 1 red apple, 1 anjou pear, 1 mango, 1 pineapple and some strawberries.  I never add any sugar (it's sweet enough!) and instead use a couple spoons of homemade jam (preferably rhubarb or strawberry) mixed with a bit of lemon juice for a kick.  As for the chips, I spray the tortillas with butter spray, top and bottom, cut them into triangles and place them on a cookie sheet.  Then I sprinkle them with the cinnamon/sugar mixture and pop them in the 350 oven.  I don't know for how long, maybe 10 mins, I just keep an eye on them so they don't burn.  I've never had anyone NOT ask me for this recipe!  It's so nice and refreshing... and most of all, it's healthy!!!

text:
This is such a fantastic treat and something different! First batch we made with 2 kiwi, 1 peach, raspberries, a granny smith and a 'grapple' (it's an apple, but smells & tastes like a white grape!) & cherry preserves. Second batch was with rasperries, strawberries, 1/2 a fugi and 1/2 a granny smith, 2 kiwi and 1 peach. You never have to have the same taste twice unless you want and it's fun to experiment. The chips were super, as I think the 2nd spray of Pam kept the cinn./sugar on.  I wanted to take something light to a 4th of July gathering and this was a hit! Will make this a lot! Thanks for sharing!

text:
This is so refreshing. I used frozen berry mix, fresh strawberries and apples (left out kiwi).I used one tsp. of equal and 1 Tblsp. brown sugar...it was sweet enough. I put the fruit in the food processor and pulsed for a few seconds. This chopped it up nicely and is a timesaver. I also cut the tortillas with a pizza cutter and baked in a muffin tin.

text:
I really liked this recipe, although it did not go over as well at my party as I had hoped for all the previous rave reviews.  The chips were definitely more popular than the salsa.  I loved them together. I did reduce the white sugar by half and the preserves by a third (using 1 T. strawberry and 1 T. apricot). I also added mango and blueberries, which were really good.  I would not leave out the apple as it adds a little crunchiness to the salsa. The chips were very time consuming to make, but very tasty. I will try it again, but with a different group of people. Thanks for sharing your recipe.

I served this at a Longaberger basket party and it didn't go over too well.  The fruit was mushy and purple-looking, and most people just tasted it and didn't finish their helpings.  The chips were good the night before, fresh out of the oven; however, I stored them overnight in an airtight container, and they still tasted stale the next day.  I will probably make the chips by themselves again to serve as a snack hot out of the oven, but I won't try the fruit salsa again.

text:
Everyone who tried this liked it.  I made the salsa as written, but did coat the chips on both sides with cinnamon and sugar and then pressed the wedges into muffin tins so they were shaped like scoops.  I used non-stick muffin tins and made sure to spray the tins really well with cooking spray and removed the chips immediately after taking them out of the oven so I had no problems with them sticking to the tins.  I made the chips the night before and they were fine the next morning.

text:
While I enjoyed this, I wasn't as wowed as I hoped to be. My husband hates fruit, so I made a half batch of this for myself. Despite others warning to avoid adding sugar, I did anyways - and I'm glad I did. My fruit must have been super tart or else I'm a TOTAL sweet tooth because even with it (and 1 1/2 T peach preserves), my salsa wasn't sweet enough for my liking. My chips were also only mildly sweet. The real disappointment however, is that this doesn't keep well AT ALL. You really need to eat this in one sitting, which is why it's perfect for parties (but even then, this will start looking pretty dull the longer it sits). All said and done, this was fun to try but nothing to write home about (sorry!). Thanks anyways, Annie. :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I have made this, and I followed the recipe as written both times. This is always a hit, both the salsa and the chips. I also sprayed both sides of the tortillas and then sprinkled one side with cinnamon sugar and stacked them up and then cut them into wedges with a pizza cutter, in stacks of about 3 at a time. I baked them on a pizza stone and they came out nice and crispy without browning too much. I made them the night before and kept in a zip lock bag and they were still fresh and crispy the next evening. I was glad I did because I needed the time the next day to chop all the fruit small. It was well worth it, a great recipe. I used the left over fruit the next morning with blueberry pancakes, delicious. You could make this a day ahead.

text:
I saved these in my recipe box for years, thinking surely I'd have a reason to serve them someday. I finally did for a Mexican potluck at my school when I wasn't asked to bring a main dish as I usually am. This was simple to make (I actually LOVE chopping fruit) and I cheated by buying Stacey's brand cinnamon pita chips for dipping. The bowl was scraped clean and several people asked for the recipe. Thanks for a great dish.

text:
Yum! Just made this for the first time and it was delish! I followed the advice of another review and did not add sugar to the fruit. It was still very sweet! I also did not want to have to deal with apples browning so I skipped the apple and added diced fresh black plums for extra tang and peach preserves.  I used whole wheat tortillas and melted together butter, raw sugar and cinnamon. I brushed this on the tortillas before I cut and baked. Perfection! I will def make this again. Thank you!!!

text:
I've made this several times, I don't use raspberries, I sub it with frozen peaches and add blueberries. I am not a big fan of sugar so I don't add any. I put it in the fridge and leave it sit for about an hour or more and the natural juices sweeten it enough. BUT the chip I make exactly as described. They should be called CRACK CHIPS because they are so awesome!!!  I love in Florida - where its always HOT here so its a perfect dish and I always have someone who want the recipe from me.  LOVE IT!! thanks for sharing it!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for years and I always have people begging me to make this. I do change the recipe a bit though, I use a pound of strawberries, a mango, a pear, a red delicious apple, and 2 kiwi. I dice all of the fruit and add 2 tablespoons of white sugar and let it sit overnight. The cinnamon chips are so delicious but you have to keep an eye on them, one second they are too soft and the next second they can burn. For special occasions I cut the tortillas into shapes using cookie cutters.

BEST RECIPE!! I have made this MANY times. It is always a hit with adults and kids alike. My son had taken this to school for his birthday snack for the last 2 years because he loves it. I don't use all of the sugar. I stack the tortillas as I season them. Then I cut about 5 of them with the pizza cutter all at once. text:
I took this to a baby shower and it was a hit! I followed some of the recommendations of other reviewers and tweaked the recipe slightly. I sprayed my tortillas on both sides, cut them into wedges with a pizza cutter. In a gallon size zip lock bag I mixed 2 c. sugar to 2 t. cinnamon. I dropped the tortilla wedges into the bag gave the bag a few good shakes to coat each wedge. I baked them in the oven for about 10 minutes. For the fruit salsa, I cut up strawberries, raspberries, kiwis, mango, pineapple, and fuji apples. I omitted the sugar and instead added 2 T. of peach preserves which made it plenty sweet and didn't make too much liquid. A very good recipe!

This sounds like a great recipe so I am making it this weekend! I noticed alot of people are having trouble with apples browning so I will offer a hint. If you soak the apples after cutting them up in pineapple juice they wont brown! It has something to do with the acidity. Plus you can add the pineapples to the salsa!
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2010-01-02T16:44:24.087

userID:
3203787
Display Name:
Alwyn1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read many reviews before making this, and it helped me a lot. I skipped the sugar, added both apricot and strawberry jam to taste, you really don't need much. I used fiji apples, adding them last as I had read, and they didn't turn brown at all. I used 4 kiwis and a frozen mixture of strawberry/peach/mango I bought and chopped. As I was taking it to an adult only party, I poured a couple of tablespoons of blackberry liquor over it... YUMMY!!! Got many raves!!  I made the chips the day before, and kept in an airtight container, they were crisp and yummy. To cut down on time, I found the easiest way to make them was to put one tortilla on the counter and spray with butter flavor and then shake on some cinnamon sugar, then lightly spray and place the next right on top, rotate it a little to get the extra sugar from the bottom one and repeat until you have 6. Then cut with pizza cutter in 8ths and bake on cookie sheets for 12 min (or until you see the edges start to brown slightly). Don't take them out too early or they will be tough and taste stale. I mixed plain and WW tortillas. It was well worth the effort, as it was a star amongst the usual deep fried party fare, and esp at new years when everyone is on the verge of their resolutions, my fruit salsa was all gone and the fattening stuff was left over!! If you are wondering whether to try this recipe, go for it, it is very forgiving, you can customize it to suit you and everyone will love it! Enjoy and THANKS Annie!

text:
This is a good recipe.  For the salsa, I just chopped up fruit and added NOTHING else (strawberry, kiwi, canteloupe, gala apple, & fresh pineapple)--wonderful!! For the chips, brush one side of a tortilla with soft butter & sprinkle with sugar/cinnamon.  Then cut and bake til lightly crisp.  Don't overbake.  This step was timeconsuming.  Don't make them too far in advance, b/c they get stale.

text:
I followed another person's suggestion and used a plastic bag to shake the chips in the cinnamon and sugar which allows you to enjoy cinnamon on both sides. I found that cooking time took about three minutes longer in order to make them crispy due to the additional cinnamon sugar...but it was well worth it.  I followed someone's suggestion and used Fuji apples to avoid browning.  I took the additional precaution of cutting up the apples last and shaking them in a plastic bag with sweetened lime juice before adding them to the salsa.  This worked very well.  I used Boysenberry preserves in the salsa.  The recipe turned out to be delicious.  I am so glad that there were so many reviews because from the title, I do not think I would have tried it.  But it is amazing!

text:
This recipe is delicious.  My entire family loves it and it's become my signature dish for family gatherings.  I use Granny Smith apples and replace the raspberries with blueberries. But I've tried it with other things, and it's always good. 

The only big change I make is to bake the tortillas for much longer than recommended to make them crispy.  I usually sprinkle one side with the cinnammon/sugar and bake for 8-10 minutes.  Then I flip them over, sprinkle the other side and bake them for another 10-12 minutes.  Otherwise, they come out a little rubbery.  

But overall, still delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/253424.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a modified version of this recipe last night in under 30 minutes. It was a total hit with absolutely none left. 

For the salsa, I used 1 banana, 1 cup of chopped strawberries, 1 kiwi, 1/3 (or about 1/2 to 3/4 cup) of a Braeburn apple, & 1/2 cup chopped blueberries. I drizzled honey over top and mixed thoroughly.

For the chips, I took 3 medium sized flour tortillas and cut them with pizza cutter into 8 triangles each. I used 1/2 stick of melted unsalted butter and dredged the pieces into the butter then into the sugar-cinnamon mix. Baked for about 12 minutes and slid them off the cookie sheet into a bowl. 

I literally served these within 15 minutes of making it and everyone loved them! Will make again and again.

I made this as a snack for a weekly Bible study group and was told it was the best snack the group has ever been served!  As warned by reviewers, I eliminated the sugar and preserves and found they weren't needed - the sweetness was just right without it! Excellent recipe.  I used Granny Smith apples and added diced fresh pineapple (this also counters the browning with apples), omitted the lemon juice and sugars(sugar will draw out the fruit's natural juice and make the salsa go runny and soft, alot faster).  I did add 2T apple jelly for some added sweetness. I also lightly brushed low fat tortillas with butter, instead of using 'butter' spray.

This was awesome, everyone at my church community group loved it. I doubled it, except the apples (used 3 not 4) and didn't double the white/brown sugar, only used as much as the original recipe called for. I don't yet have a "good" food processor that chops/dices, so this took me about 4 hours total, and the tortillas took the longest to make, but it was well worth all the time it took.

userID:
963725
Display Name:
Evie
isPro:
False
followersCount:

madeRecipesCount:
40
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can only comment on the cinnamon chips as that is all I made. I paired them up with a private recipe of kiwi salsa and it was a great match.

Don't understand all the fuss in the reviews about how to make the chips mess free. I used whole wheat tortillas, cut it into 8 pieces (like a pizza), brushed on MELTED BUTTER (didn't like the idea of butter from a can), pressed the buttered side into a plate of a equal mix of sugar and cinnamon, laid them all out on stone baking pan, in the oven for the recommended time, and VIOLA, they came out PERFECT. Crisp, yummy. Didn't bother with the sticking them in the muffin pan trick a lot of reviewers suggested bez that only meant more pans for me to clean up and would slow down the number I could pop in the oven in one time. But why bother? I provided a small spoon in the salsa that people used to scoop onto the flat crispy tortilla triangle and it was no problem for anyone. Easy, no mess, no bother, great tasting!

text:
Made this for a pool party. It was a huge hit. Ran out of Cinnamon Chips pretty quickly. I would definitely suggest doubling the recipe. One of the other reviews suggested using Tostitos flour tortillas. I tried this and they didn't turn out at all. The cinnamon sugar didn't stick and they were salty. So I went with the original version and they turned out great. As far as the salsa; I didn't add any sugar. I used apricot preserves, 1 lb of strawberries, 2 kiwi, 1 nectarine, 2 fugi apples, and champagne grapes (these happened to be in season). The grapes were a great addition but a bit time consuming getting them off the vine. Everyone asked for the recipe.

text:
Wonderful recipe!!!  Deserves more than just 5 stars!!! I actually had a recipe for similar chips made out of pita's.  I use the whole wheat ones...I seperate them, then cut them up just like this recipe says.  My family and I like them better than the tortilla's, but a bit harder to work with(I tried both).  I also used pizza cutter and butter spray, and then shook them in a bag/container...then baked them in muffin tins to curve them, for easier dipping. After one batch, I lined the tins...makes for easier clean up(as the sugar melts and hardens and eventually burns on).  Didn't use any added sugar in the fruit, and it was perfect.  I added grapes too...which I really liked! And the apples are a must...for the crunch. Terific recipe.  Time consuming, but oh so worth it!

So good! Big hit at my BBQ yesterday. For chips I found that Good Earth Fruit Crisps (Berry and Apple Cinnamon) were the most popular with the salsa. I also made the chips in the recipe and they were well received too. Stacy's Pita Chips were barely touched.

text:
I would give it 10 stars if there as sucha thing! :o) i loved this recipe! amazing! everytime i make it, everyone asks for the recipe! i did make the tortilla chips a little different and i found them to come out much better: i cut the tortillas into triangles and i fried them in veg oil until light brown. and let the oil drain on a paper towel. In a bowl i combinded the cinnamon and sugar to taste. then i tossed the "chips" until well coated in the cinnamon and sugar. i like making them like this because they come out more "chip like" and r super quick to make! they r so good i sometimes eat them alone! :o)   Thanks so much for the recipe!

country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe for Easter brunch. It went over pretty well. I made it the night before, but waited to add the sugar until the morning I was going to serve it. I only ended up adding about 2T. of brown sugar. I omitted the white sugar and the preserves. I served it with store bought  cinnamon/sugar pita chips. Everyone really seemed to like it. I did not have any trouble with my apples turning brown, in fact, everything was a nice red color. This makes quite a bit, so make sure you know how many people you will be serving. I had quite a bit leftover since I had so much food at the party. Later in the week, I added a bit more fruit and some flour to thicken it. I also added more brown sugar some cinn and nutmeg. Then I made an apple crisp topping and baked it for about 30 min. It was delicious served with vanilla ice cream.

I wanted to find a light and refreshing appetizer for a spring get together with a few friends. This fit the bill. text:
I tried a small amount of chips with melted butter and they were great so couldn't wait to get the  butter spray and do a whole batch. I followed the suggestions of doing 4 at a time as I LOVE easy! But they were nothing compared to doing one at a time. The butter spray went all over the sink and doing both sides made them stick to the pan. Plus they were way too sugary. I threw them out and started again using real melted butter and doing just one side and they were perfection. A 100% difference. It took me 25 minutes - not more than the "easy" way. A wonderful refreshing salsa. Thanks.

text:
This was great! I used 2 GD apples and one Fuji, I think. I forgot kiwis while at the store, and used 16 oz frozen strawberries, and I think a 10 or 12 oz bag of frozen sweetened raspberries. I chopped up everything but the strawberries. Only added the brown sugar because the raspberries were already sweetened. And I used pineapple apricot preserves. It turned out fantastic. My fiance thought the chips were too sweet so I made a couple trays worth with just the butter spray and no cinnamon sugar which turned out well for those that didn't have the crazy sweettooth that I have! This turned out really great, and we had them over pancakes with whipped cream the next morning as suggested by another review. I'll definitely make this again, everyone loved it!

text:
Absolutely AMAZING!  I made a Mexican themed meal for company and served this for desert with some really great vanilla ice cream.  I did follow the directions exactly, except I added balsamic vinegar to compliment the berries (trust me) and a finely diced jalapeno.  Everyone was amazed by how well it all worked and really enjoyed the slight kick from the jajapeno.  The cinnamon chips were so easy, I toasted them first then threw them in a large zip lock bag with the cinnamon and sugar mix and shook well.  The presentation was really great, a large scoop of ice cream surrounded by four wedges of cinnamon chips and a generous amount of the salsa on top.  My guests were floored!  The preparation was really simple all around.  I did add a touch of lime to the salsa since I was making it a few hours in advance.

text:
I first made this at our "girls night" get together & it was a HUGE hit. Now whenever there's a family or office potluck I am asked to make it. I did however use diff fruits - I used 2 apples, sm.container of blueberries & a sm.container of rasberries, and to watch sugar intake I used Splenda instead of white sugar and used the Smucker's Sugar Free Preserves (any flavor will do).  Also if it's not quite "juicy" enough I use about 2tbls of crushed pinapple to act as "glue".  I also found if you squirt a little lemon or lime juice on the apples prior to mixing in everything else, it keeps the apples from turning!

text:
This recipe is phenomenal!  I made it for a Mexican themed party lastnight and it was so summery!  Please don't let comments that it takes long turn you off, I think it took me a total of 45 minutes for everything and it was worth every second!  The chips turned out great too, so tasty (I snacked on a few on the way to the party!) Anyhow, the recipe doesn't state if you should chop the strawberries and raspberries but I did dice the strawberries.  The raspberries ended up condensing as you fold the ingredients.  Best of luck and enjoy!

P.S. It does make a lot, I even took extra to work the next day!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was an outstanding recipe.  It was beautiful to serve and tasty to eat. I did not use the raspberries in the recipe because several of my friends do not care for them. Even without the raspberries it was delicious (and less costly). I substituted Gala apples for the Red Delicious, I find that there is a huge difference in quality of taste between the two types. When making the tortilla chips, instead of sprinkling the cinnamon-sugar mixture on, I placed the mixture in a Ziploc bag and coated the tortillas that way (I believe I used 2 cups of sugar and 4 teaspoons of cinnamon). I also cut down on the fat content by brushing the tortillas with water instead of using the cooking oil. They turned out great, lots of cinnamon-sugar coating and very crunchy (great for dipping). I will absolutely make this again. It is one of the tastiest dishes I have made in a long time. Thanks so much for contributing this addition to my recipe book.

text:
Everybody in the office loved it.  It does take a bit of time to prepare (all that washing, chopping, etc.) but it looks great, tastes great and is pretty healthy to boot.  Someone suggested putting the cut-up tortillas in a bag of cinnamon sugar and shaking to coat.  I did it that way and the chips had way too much coating -- the cinnamon stuck, and the sugar didn't so the cinnamon flavor was overpowering .  So I prefer to prepare the chips the way the recipe says.

ANTINA5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good the first day and awsome the second.  I did change things a little, as fresh berries weren't in season when I made it.  I used 1 apple, 1 pear, 2 kiwis and a bag of frozen mixed berries.  I added lime juice to the apple and pear to prevent browness and cut back on the sugar (I only used the brown sugar).  I also did not use any preserves as the juice from the berries and the brown sugar made it juicy enough.  I think the lime juice is what really helped off set the sweetness.  Also, when making the tortillas I found it was easier to spray the tortillas and then dredge in cinnamon/sugar, cut and then spray again.  Great recipe, and I can't wait to make now that strawberries are coming into season!

userID:
2150076
Display Name:
sophie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/225914.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i like to do most of the prep for a party ahead of time - you cannot do that with this recipe, hence the 4 star rating.  Plus it doesn't keep well, AND the chopping is time consuming. It is delicious as written - but is also tremendously flexible, which I love. Depending upon where (and to whom) it is being served, I might add a splash of orange or blackberry liquor. Toss in a few blackberries or blueberries. I use less sugar, and a little more jam. I might add a leaf of mint. (Remove before serving, and don't add too much!) Change anything you want to make it your own - or keep it exact. Delicious however. I alway chop the fruit into tiny pieces. Tiny. Tiny.  The liquid it releases then becomes a part of the salsa, and you don't have fruit salad drowning in its' own juice. I serve it with a small spoon, rather than trying to 'dip' the chips.  Also use packaged cinnamon sugar pita chips or bagel rounds, they go fast! If there is any left - serve it over cheesecake, ice cream, or use as an accent for strawberry shortcake.  YUM!

city:

country:

text:
I do not like eating fruit. I only like unripe sort of fruit, which is rare to find at just the right degree of ripeness (I don't like mooshy, I don't like citrus..) So, I planned to make this for 4th of July, for others, because the picture that use to be up was very pretty. I made this with a variety of fruits, and I cubed them all about 1/4" each, then halved blueberries. I used orange preserve, let it soak overnight, lazily grabbed a bag of pita cinnamon & sugar chips & called it a day. Because I have to try it before serving, I tried it. Oh, my, goodness. I actually liked....no....LOVED it. I have never said I loved anything fruit, unless it's cherry ice cream, which isn't really fruit at all, as much as I pretend!  This was gone in a matter of minutes at the cookout, and I have made it several times with a variety of fruits available, but always strawberry and kiwi and orange preserve. Try it, you won't be sorry.

This is a great and forgiving recipe. You can easily add or substitute whatever fruits you have on hand. I modified it to low sugar, low carb, higher fiber, and  fat free and still got a 5 star Picky Philly rating. AMAZING given Picky Philly is fruit and vegetable adverse!

text:
We don't care for raspberries in our house so I used fresh or frozen peaches depending on the season and we love it! I switch up the fruit preserves depending on what I have and it is equally delicious. This is great for any season and we like it served with some fruit dip made with marshmallow crème, cream cheese and Cool Whip combined on the side. This is not the figure friendly version but great for a special occasion and looks great served in a "cloud" of this white fluffiness! Use a small jar of marshmallow crème, one package of cream cheese at room temperature and one small carton of Cool Whip, mix with a mixer and chill. Delicious!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this but I made changes to accomidate our tastes and what others suggested. I use finely chopped fresh strawberries,apples that we eat (gala, eve, jazz or honeycrisp) pears and kiwis. I dont use any fruit that has been frozen we dont like the soggy texture and I peel the apples and pears. I make my own frozen low sugar strawberry jam and add several heaping spoonfuls. No added sugar at all other than the jam. The tortillas after spraying(I spray them in my roaster pan to reduce mess)and slicing I dredge them in the cinnamon/sugar mixture but dont press them into the mixture or they become too sweet. cooking them for 10 minutes is perfect for us, super crunchy. after the tortillas come out of the oven I flip them over to let the undersides dry to make sure they are extra crispy.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4498081.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so delicious! I used these fruits (not everything is in season in December, and I wanted more variety): 1 cup pomegranate arils, 1 lb frozen stawberries (thawed, diced, and drained), 3/4 cup frozen blueberries, 1/2 cup frozen peaches, 3/4 cup blackberries (quartered), 1 Junami apple, and 2 kiwis. I only added about 1 tbsp white sugar and used apricot preserves. I served it with cinnamon-sugar pita chips I found at the grocery store. Everyone absolutely loved this, and even used it on the seafood at dinner! Next time, I will use fresh strawberries, though - even with draining them, it was a little watery after it sat for a few hours. Thanks for a great customizable recipe!

This was very good but I will definitely cut down the white sugar to 1 tbs next time.  I used apricot preserves.  Another tip is to use wonton wrappers for the chips. text:
This is awesome!! We made the chips as stated in the recipe and used fuji apples, raspberries, strawberries, peaches, kiwi, and blueberries in the fruit salsa. Plain old grape jam works great for the preserves, and we did add some white and brown sugar as called for in the recipe. The sugar seemed necessary to us, to cut out some of the bitterness in the berries - but I'm sure this depends heavily on personal preference. It turned out great! We'll be making this again :D

region:

country:
None
text:
UPDATE: a day or 2 after when this was quite soggy looking I used the leftovers up by blending with ice and a little bit of fruit juice. It made a delicious slushy fruit drink! This was just excellent. I made the fruit salsa as stated but you could definitely use any of your favorite fruit combos. The chips I did a little differently though, I cut up tortillas, brushed them (ok, dunked them – it was faster!) in melted butter and then shook in a zip loc with brown sugar, white sugar and cinnamon to coat. They took me about 14 minutes to bake at 350 and took several batches to get a significant number of chips. I found that there was way more salsa than chips with this recipe. Either way, they were gobbled up and so yummy! I definitely plan to put this into a regular party food rotation.

Really disappointed with this... As written, the recipe has way too much apple and not enough kiwi.  Apple was all you could see or taste and the kiwi disappeared to nothing.  Thought 3 T of fruit perserves was way too much - would make it like a glaze - so used 2 T and was still WAY too much.  Plus the sugar made all the fruit release their juice so it was just mushy fruit slop - didn't hold the diced shape at all.  Am so disappointed I haven't even bothered to make the cinnamon chips cuz the salsa doesn't look appetizing enough to scoop up  :(

text:
I absolutely love this recipe! I've made it on several occasions and received rave reviews each time. I half the amount of raspberries and add blueberries in their place. I also use half granny smith, half gala apples instead of the golden delicious. And I leave the skin on the apples -- no need to waste time on peeling when the skin adds some texture and color to the mixture. I've used pineapple, strawberry and raspberry jam and they all work great. For the cinnamon chips, I coat both sides of the tortillas with the cinnamon sugar and then bake them in cupcake tins for a "scoop-like" chip as another poster recommended. Love it, love it, love it!!

text:
This is a spectacular recipe and I will definitely be making again soon. I followed the recipe pretty closely with the following changes: 1) I cut the tortillas into wedges and sprayed both sides with butter. I then added them to a big baggie filled with my cinnamon-sugar mixture and just shook the bag until they were all coated. Made for a very easy cleanup. 2) I couldn't find any raspberries, so I just used more kiwi and raspberry preserves. 3) I used FIJI apples! I First sliced the apples into quarters and then dipped the apples in lemon juice before chopping up to prevent browning. 4) I didn't use the full amount of sugars suggested as my fruits were pretty sweet already, so I just sprinkled a bit of white and bit of brown sugar.  I got rave reviews from my guests and they are looking forward to the next time I make this!

text:
I get rave reviews and lots of impressed people every time I make this.  My only complaint is that it takes sooo long to do!  I made a double batch and it took 3.5 hours (2 on chips, 1.5 on cutting fruit).  For the chips, I slice with a pizza cutter, spray both sides with butter, and shake in a plastic bag of cinnamon & sugar.  I stopped using brown sugar because it's plenty sweet already.  Probably just adding the preserves would be enough.  Will make again, but not too often just because of time!

text:
You HAVE to try this recipe:  There's a reason it has 1500+ high ratings. If I could give this 10 stars, I would, it's THAT good!  Like others, I did change it up a little... I tossed the diced (gala) apples in a few tablespoons lime juice to prevent browning; I added no sugar whatsoever; I also added blueberries.  With the chips, I found the cheaper flour tortillas, the thicker kind that are on the shelf, were better than the more expensive refrigerated kind.  That's just my opinion.  Also, I sprayed the chips (after cutting the rounds into quarters with a pizza cutter), cinnamon-sugared them, resprayed, then second coated with cinnamon sugar.  They were awesome by themselves.  I 1 1/2 times'd this recipe and it made 1/2 gallon of salsa... which was the only food at the party that was gone before it was over.

Absolutely delicious.  I put in blueberries instead of raspberries and skipped the bananas.  I used Fuji apples and Red Raspberry preserves.  I also cut back on both the sugar and the preserves, using about half of what it called for. I also only used one apple.  The tortillas were incredibly easy to make and a huge hit at the party I took them to.  Everyone wanted to know how I made them and what I used.  All in all, delicious and a big hit!

text:
I have made this recipe a couple times now and it has not dissapointed!!  I LOVE this!  I do add blueberries and red seedless grapes as well....but do not increase the sugars.  I think the blueberries are a must for the tartness and the color they bring to this recipe.  I chop everything mildly with my pampered chef chopper and it comes out perfect!  This is intended to be more of a watery recipe....like salsa....so if you are looking for something firmer I would suggest only slicing the fruit and not adding the extra sugars.  This recipe is a hit with everyone!  Especially my kids!!  My 18 month old wants to eat the salsa with a spoon....as do I ;)

I made this for our Christmas Eve party, and it was a HUGE hit! I used strawberry preserves, and chilled for a couple of hours. text:
I just made this for the second time for a ladies lunchoen and it was gone within 10 minutes. I reccomend doubling (if not more) this recipe because it goes so fast. I modified this recipe the following ways; I added a small package of blueberries and blackberries, omitted the sugar and I put half of the strawberries in the food proccesor to give the dip a thicker consistency - I sliced the other half. I used apricot preserves and bought the Pita Cinnamon Chips at Trader Joes. For me this was much neater than making my own chips, less time consuming too. Delicious!

So the apples didn't get brown I cut them up and let them soak in "Sprite" since there is lemon in it.  This doesn't give it a different flavor & cuts down on the oxidation. When I was ready to serve, I drained the apples & mixed them into the salsa.  This is a great recipe & it goes far.

our family loves this, and it's popular wherever we take it! I do not add raspberries (although I will try it that way sometime!), and leave out the white sugar. I add a bit of orange zest and use apricot preserves. I also spray the tortillas with a spritx of olive oil, then the sugar/cinnamon.

userID:
2732416
Display Name:
Joan Newman
isPro:

8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1274255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is deserving of more than 5 stars because everyone just loves it.  Both the chips as well as the fruit are excellent.  I cut the strawberries and kiwis into larger pieces and arrange some of the raspberries on top to maximize the attractiveness of the fruit. I add extra kiwi as that color gets a little lost otherwise. I only use one apple and have not had a problem with it turning brown. I think the other fruits as well as the preserves keep it from darkening. You could toss the apple with pineapple or citrus fruit juice to be on the safe side. Then just drain the juice off.  In place of one of the apples, I like to add either a mango, peach or nectarine. I do cut down the sugar quite a bit depending on the sweetness of the fruit I am using. I like to use peach preserves as it does not discolor the fruit. The chips are a little delicate so I store them in a container rather than a baggie. Thank you for such a wonderful recipe.  I have shared this recipe often and have used it on a number of special occasions.

text:
Use real melted butter instead of the flavored spray and brush it on with a pastry brush!  I used the spray and no one ate the first round, but when I made them with real butter people became feinds for it!  I also layered the prepared tortillas then sliced them with a pizza cutter to speed up prep time.  I tried the "muffin tin" suggestion, and while they were more scoopable, they didn't get the bubbly crisp texture that baking them on a flat baking sheet gives.

text:
So delicious. I had no problems with mess with the chips. I cut them all with a pizza cutter and placed them on a baking sheet lined with foil. Then I sprayed them all and sprinkled them with the cinnamon sugar. No mess! You don't need the cinnamon sugar on both sides... For the salsa, I tossed the apples in a bit of lemon juice, so no browning. I also used frozen, drained raspberries. So delicious! I took this to a tailgate and everyone raved about it!

text:
Wow! This was a major hit at the barbecue I brought it to. Everyone was asking "what is this and who made it?" I even heard a couple of "I can't stop eating this" comments. I went with what looked good at the market for fruits, and used pineapple, mango, strawberries and kiwi with raspberry preserves. I will say it took a lot longer to prepare than I expected with all that peeling and dicing but the flavor was worth it. I also added a bit of lime zest and a squeeze of lime juice. A word of advice about the cinnamon chips (which are awesome!). Use parchment on your baking sheet and cleanup will be easier.

text:
This is an excellent recipe. I used frozen peaches and strawberries and used fresh apples (fuji), and pears. I omitted the kiwis for the time being. I also used strawberry preserves. I did put a little bit of white sugar on the fruit, but will probably omit that the next time b/c it was slightly sweet (but good). 
I bought corn tortillas instead of flour tortillas on accident. The chips tasted fine, but I had to cook them about 15-20 minutes. I like them crunchy and so it took longer to get the crunch I wanted. 
Overall, this is an excellent recipe and I will be making it again.

text:
A friend brought this to a neighborhood BBQ and I loved it. She told me about allrecipes.com and I've been making it ever since.
My only variation is that I cut all of my chips, lay them on wax paper and spray BOTH sides. Then instead of 'sprinkling' cinnamon sugar on them, I put them in a ziplock bag with cinn/sug and shake it. They end up coming out of the oven so crispy! Everyone asks me to bring this along, now.
I tried frozen raspberries and strawberries, but the recipe always comes out too watery and mushy. So I use fresh always.

text:
Like everyone else I found this fantastic!  To save some money (fresh fruit can be expensive!) I used the frozen fruit from the freezer section.  I did use fresh strawberries and kiwis but I put in frozen blueberries, raspberries and peaches.  I didn't use any of the extra sugar and I tell you I'm glad I didn't.  It was perfectly sweet.  The first time I made it I made my own chips but after that I bought store chips.  I found the fresh chips good but time consuming and I couldn't get them consistantly crispy.  
I liked this so much I shared it with my receipe group last month.  Enjoy!

text:
I thought this was a very unique dessert idea. I thought the fruit salsa was too sweet so I would reduce the jam and sugar. The chips were amazing but one tip is do not try this with whole wheat tortillas. I did one batch with the whole wheat to see how they taste but they were no good. So, splurge and eat the regular white ones. I also highly recommend to serve the fruit over vanilla ice cream and stick a few chips out of the top of the ice cream. It makes for a nice presentation and a great mix of flavors.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OUTSTANDING!!!!!!  I made this for our family Labor Day get together, and it was a huge hit.  I only added 1 TBSP of white sugar, omitted the brown sugar entirely, and it was plenty sweet.  I used strawberries, kiwi, and apples in ours with 3 TBSP Polaner All Fruit Strawberry preserves.  The chips were not hard to make - I used olive oil and brushed it onto each tortilla, stacked them, then cut with a pizza cutter.  Threw the cinnamon/sugar mixture into a ziploc and shook a few tortilla slices around before laying them on a cookie sheet lined with parchment paper.  Next time, I may try a large bowl for coating so I can make sure all of the surfaces get a good dusting of the cinnamon/sugar.  (BTW - you can't taste the olive oil at all once they are baked, and I figure it's better for you than spray out of a can.  :oP)

My mother even asked for this recipe - it's that good.  I plan on taking it to a Ladies' Retreat at church later this month.  

Thanks so much!  This one is going in my permanent file.  :o)

text:
This was a hit.  I made the chips the night before...don't use Weight Watchers butter spray, yucky taste on the chips. After I cut them I put them in muffin tins to bake so they came out curved and easier for dipping in the salsa!  I would suggest halving the recipe for a small crowd...you could use 1/2 the amounts for everything and still have a good amount without wasting. I also replaced blueberries  for kiwis and used one granny smith apple and one golden delicious. Pretty easy and impressed, give it a shot!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe.  It was fun and something different.  I changed a few things though.  I didn't do the apples because I was afraid they would turn brown.  Instead I did diced strawberries, blueberries and kiwi fruit.  I added a bit less sugar than was called for and omitted the preserves.  For the cinnamon chips I didn't have any cooking spray so I brushed melted butter on one side of the tortillas and sprinkled them VERY generously with cinnamon sugar.  I cut them into triangles and baked them until they were golden brown (careful not to over bake.)  I then took whipping cream and added sugar and a touch of  vanilla to it and whipped it up.  This dish looked very pretty with the salsa, whipped cream and chips.  It is a fun dish to bring to a party as an appetizer or dessert.

text:
Incredible idea and very versatile.  The chips are perfect just the way they are, and entertaining for the neighbors as they watched me make them outside to cut down the mess in my kitchen.  The sugar is an unecessary addition to the salsa as long as you use a good mix of sweet and sour fruit fruit.  My first batch I used papaya instead of raspberry, and put in raspberry preserves instead.  The second batch I added peaches and sprinkled them with just a dash of key lime juice.  Took both to an art show and had people coming up to me and asking if there was more hidden away somewhere.  Friends a state away heard about it and were calling me for the recipe.  Absolutely marvelous and looks beautiful for a summer event.

Absolutely wonderful!  People ask me to do this all the time.  Using basically the same recipe, I have used the same amount of apples and kiwi but have changed the raspberries and strawberries and use fresh pineapple and fresh or frozen peaches (I use the recipe amounts for raspberries=pineapple and strawberries=peaches) and then I use orange marmalade or apple jelly for the jam. (you can coat with sugar/cin. mix warm or cold)

text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC.  As a previous reviewer suggested, I used mini-muffin cups to create more of a "scoop" effect with the chips.  I also coated both sides of the tortillas with cinnamon sugar, making a sweeter, thicker, and more crisp chip; I then left out the sugar in the salsa so that overall it wasn't too sweet.  This recipe was a huge hit; it received many compliments.  One suggestion: you might want to double it!  It goes quickly!!!

text:
AWESOME!  I've been making this for a couple years now.  Easy to make but time consuming with all that dicing especially when making it on a large scale.  I don't find the need for the sugar or preserves but sometimes I taste before I add the sugar and only add if it needs it. Also any combo of fruits seems to be possible.  I generally use apples, grapes, strawberries and kiwi. The cinnamon chips are such a yummy dipping option.  A low cal treat that hits the spot like a fruit pie would! I'm on weight watchers and I can get 12 chips (2 one pt tortillas) and 1/2 cup of the salsa for 3 points!

text:
This recipe was a big hit last night for my women's group.  I used half of the sugar and I did not use the preserves.  I also cut the apples last, and dipped them in a lemon juice and water mixture to prevent them from browning.
The cinnamon chips were the perfect addition to the fruits!  I sprayed them with the cooking oil and cut them, then I put them into a large plastic bag with the cinnamon and sugar mixture and shook until well coated.
I also served mine with whipped cream...yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was excellent! I made it yesterday for a cinco de mayo party and it was a hit!! I put alot of the reviews together and this is what I came up with-I used 12 inch flour tortillas and cut them  in half and then did triangle cuts which actually ended up w/alot, but the perfect size.  Next time I won't get so many unless I want some left over, in which I had today along w/extra dip I saved and the whole thing was awesome (I think better than yesterday) .  So, I used spray butter on one side and then cut them w/a pizza cutter which made it so easy and sprinkled w/already mixed from the store cinnamon sugar.  Baked at 350 degrees for 8 min. in muffin pans which was perfect.  I stored them in a plastic bag because I did this early in the morning to get it out of the way.  I used 1 lb. strawberries, 2 kiwis, 1 mango, 1 container blueberries, and 1 fugi apple mixed w/ a couple of spoonfuls of strawberry preserves and about a half cup of brown sugar (I didn't add the white) and it was EXCELLENT!!  Everyone raved about it and also complimented me on cutting my fruit so small (which didn't take that long) because it went perfect w/the chips!! Def. make this again and again, but might experiment next time and keep trying diff. fruit to have options!! Thanks!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I have been making this salsa for years and it has always been a big hit.  It is usually the item I am asked to bring to a party.  However, I use granny smith apples (not as sweet), strawberries, kiwi, and any other good, fresh fruit I can find, ie, pineapple, nectarines, peaches.  I also use apple jelly, a little brown sugar (1Tbsp) (or the brown sugar/splenda mix - approx 1 tsp), orange zest and a little juice/pulp from that orange.  I also spray the tortillas with water (not butter or butter spray), sprinkle with the cinnamon sugar and bake.  My kids love the chips by themselves.  I think I will try the "scoop" method though.  It will probably hold the salsa better.

text:
After reading about 100 reviews, decided to make this prior to serving it to some friends. I used strawberries, apples (1 granny smith, 1 red delicious) an asian pear, 2 kiwi, and blueberries, only 1 tbsp. brown sugar, and 3 tbsp. apricot preserves. It really was good! ( I used the 'Vidalia Chop Wizard' I had just bought and really decreased the chopping time) The chips turned out okay, baked at 400 for 4-5 min. as one reader suggested...but I think I need to experiment some more with my oven's temp. and time. It is a cool and refreshing recipe..I will serve it as an appetizer at my get-together!

text:
just another echo... great recipe for the superbowl party.  i did the tortillas like others, coating whole tortillas in a ziploc, stacking and cutting, no re-spraying.  i also stuck them in my muffin tins for sbout seven minutes, then flipped them onto a baking sheet for another three or four minutes.  they're just like low fat churros!  i also left the sugar out of the salsa, but i did use frozen raspberries and a handful of frozen blueberries.  this recipe is brilliant!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for a super-bowl party last night, and it turned out great! Everyone loved it and wanted the recipe. I took some of the other reviewers' advice on the cinnamon chips, such as buttering both sides of the tortillas first, then adding the cinnamon-sugar, and stacking them up to cut several at a time (after the sugar and butter were already on them). Also, I did not re-spray after coating them with sugar; they did not need it. I also agree with other reviewers that there is no need to add sugar to the salsa - the fruit is sweet enough as-is. Finally, I substituted one mango for the apples - a must-try in my opinion!

text:
Absolutely delicious! I had to alter the recipe a bit due to the unavailability of fruit in the winter season in Nebraska. I used 1 bag of frozen berry blend (strawberries, cherries, blackberries, raspberries, and blueberries), 2 braeburn apples, 1 bartlett pear, apricot preservers, and the rest the same as the recipe. I was surprised at the large amount that it made. I save half and used it with yogurt, ice, and fruit juice in smoothies. It was fabulous both ways. I will make this again!

I am a dedicated fruit-salad-hater, so I thought for sure I would not like this recipe at all.  Boy, was I wrong!  I practically growled at people to keep them away from this when my sister made it for our holiday celebration, and have already made it once myself.  It is SO adaptable if you have more fruits you want to add, or you want to use frozen berries instead of paying $10 for strawberries and a dinky container of raspberries.  I added a pear, frozen peaches, and blurberries to the recipe, andit was fabulous.  Making more tonight and tomorrow for myself and another get-together.  Yum!!!!

text:
This was wonderful and the women at the baby shower couldn't get enough of it! We omitted the raspberries and used all frozen strawberries instead. We used apricot jam. For less mess, we cut the tortillas into wedges and arranged them before spraying them. It didn't matter that one side of the chips were uncoated -- they were plenty sweet and crispy as is. Even the next day they were still pretty good. We used the leftover salsa as a topping on vanilla ice cream, which looked beautiful and tasted heavenly.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My GAWD is this good!  I know there are way too many reviews already, but I just HAD to add my two cents here.  I have NEVER gotten a reaction as I did with this recipe.  I used apples, and kiwis as called for as well as a mango, fresh pineapple, blueberries, strawberries, and "all fruit" strawberry preserves (the seedless variety; 3 TBSP).  I had to make the chips and salsa the night before, so I sprinkled some lime juice on the apples to prevent browning.  My pineapple turned a purty pink color (after sitting in the fridge with the other fruit all night) and I also waited to add the preserves and sugar (only 1 TBSP of white) until a couple hours before I served.  I used the ole muffin tin (4 minutes at 450 degress) and pizza cutter tricks for the chips, and although it was a bit time consuming, IT WAS WORTH IT!  I stored over night in a big ole zipper bag and simply popped the chips in a micorwave safe bowl for about 30 seconds before serving and they were perfect.  After one bite every person was hooked and everyone wanted the recipe.  AWESOME!  Thanks Annie!!!! You rock!

text:
Easy to make and wonderfully yummy.  Left out the preserves.  I also cheated by using the frozen strawberries and raspberries (they were cheaper).  I poured the whole bag in, including the juices.  Let chill overnight in fridge and strained the next day.  My family liked it so much I had to hand over the recipe!!!  One last thing, be sure to use FLOUR TORTILLAS, not corn.  Both cook well, but the flour ones are way more crispy.  Corn just tastes stale.

text:
Great! I use this with the recipe also on this site called Fluff Dip (with vanilla pudding, whipped topping, and Amaretto etc). I make the cinnamon chips by using real melted butter and brush the tortilla with a pastry brush before baking, then I sprinkle Cinnamon-Sugar on top before baking (I also cut them into wedges before baking). I also just use cut up fresh fruit along with the Fluff Dip, and serve it like chips and dip and salsa, OR I have baked a tortilla whole (spread with butter and cinnamon sugar), then when it cooled I layered on Fluff Dip and put cut fruit on top of that for a "fruit pizza". I like strawberries, mango, blueberries, pineapple and melon the best. YUM. But this recipe is great as-is also!

text:
I have made this recipe countless times, everyone loves it!  I find that using frozen raspberries, drained, instead of fresh is easire & cheaper.  I use Blackberry jam, I think it adds a nice flavor.  Also, using an egg slicer/wedger for the kiwi & strawberries really cuts down on prep time.  Just use it very slowly & carefully with the strawberries. I've made this a day or two in advance and had no problems.

text:
A wonderfully delicious and healthy new addition to my recipe box. Any fruit will do, and no extra sugar was needed, although I did add some apricot preserves. The chips were also good. I used whole wheat tortilla's, just as good as regular ones, but healthier. I used splenda instead of regular sugar and no one could tell the difference. I sprayed the tortillas very lightly and the splenda/cinnamon mixture adhered well enough. And thanks to other reviews for the tool suggestions of pizza cutter, muffin tins and Ziploc bag, it really cut this otherwise time consuming recipe down quite a bit. My family wants me to make this again this weekend. *****

dateLastModified:
2003-05-25T07:00:43.42
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
704783
Display Name:
RKI
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmmmmmmm...  I made this for a potluck at work and there were only a few chips, (I doubled up on those), and very little fruit salsa left over.  I personally didn't find this difficult to prepare at all!  I used some of the other helpful tips and applied them to my task.  Especially handy was the use of a pizza cutter for the tortillas, and the use of the muffin tins for baking the chips.  I used a food processor for chopping the fruit, and substituted blueberries for the rasberries, but left them whole since they are so small already.  It added a nice color to it.  Instead of sprinkling the cinnamon-sugar on the tortillas, I shook a few at a time in a ziplock bag which cut the time down.  The longest time in the prep work was the chip baking, and that was only because I could only bake 24 at a time due to the fact that I was limited to my muffin tins.  But I must say it was worth it!  Some of my coworkers thought I bought the chips since they looked so *professional* looking---and tasty!!  I printed out the recipe and gave out all of the ones I had, and now I need to make more since I had added requests!  I will make this again, and again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/149.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic! Hubby and I devoured these. I didn't have any apples and I don't like raspberries, so I substituted pears and mangoes, skipped the preserves and squirted liberal amounts of fresh lemon juice over it. Also, I split the cinnamon chips in batches - one batch sprayed after dredging through cinnamon sugar, and one batch unsprayed after dredging. The unsprayed batch was much crisper. Overall, it is a delicious way to use up the fresh fruit and can definitely be experimented with (although I wouldn't recommend adding bananas, as they turn mushy and ick when left to sit in juices).

text:
This recipe was a big hit at a BBQ that I went to. I made the salsa the night before and found it even better the next day.  I also added crushed pinapple to it, I noticed that with all the fresh fruit and pinapple I didn't have to add as much jam to it.  I also use a chopper to cut chop up the fruit.  That cut the time in half.  Though I think I might of chopped them a little to small, but still it turned out excellent.  I also couldn't decide on what flavor jam to use so I used both Strawberry and Aprcoit. I also found with this salsa recipe you don't have to follow it exactly and you can add other fruits to it. My oldest daughter loved the salsa, but my two other didn't care for it, but they loved the chips.  I found that if you use a pizza cutter for cuting the tortilla's it goes by much faster, I could cut 4 at a time.  I also used I cannot beleive it is Butter spray instead of Pam butter spray.  they turned out great.  I know I will make this again and again for BBQ's and parties. Thank you.

text:
This was GREAT!  PLEASE do not skip the cinnamon chips, they are incredible.  We made the recipe exactly as written (which is unusual for me, I usually make at least a few changes!), and it was perfect.  It was a big hit at a potluck that we had here at the house.  I would definately suggest letting this sit in the fridge for AT LEAST the recommended 3 hours, it allows the salsa to aquire a lot of nice juices.  The chips ARE good enough to eat by themselves, but went so well with the salsa that we only had a bit of the salsa leftover.  Thanks for an INCREDIBLE recipe.  This got raves from all, and was a very different dish than is normally seen at a potluck (or any function).  Really appreciate you sharing.

This is very tasty, maybe a little sweet, but took alot longer than 15 minutes to dice everything small enough. I cut strawberries up (recipie doesn't say whether to do that or not.)So definately allow more time than recipie says!  ALSO a quick tip, cut your tortillas into wedges with a roller type pizza cutter...you can do several at a time.  Can't wait to bring this to work and get everyones opinion!  I love it! ALSO regarding the chips, i ran out of cinnimon so had them cut up and left them lay out all afternoon....they were drying out and feeling crispy without cooking....because of this, when I did get them made they were VERY crispy!

text:
I made this for my daughter's dance team and there was NOTHING left at the end of the day!  Kids and adults both loved it!  I read some of the reviews before making it and left out the sugar.  It was plenty sweet without it.  I also sprayed the tortillas with cooking spray and shook them in a freezer bag with the sugar and cinnamon.  I think this allowed for more even coating of the chips.  Slicing up the fruit is pretty time consuming and I would recommend using a food chopper or egg slicer.  Great recipe and I will make it again!

userID:
636098
Display Name:
KATHE5020

5

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This fruit salsa is very good, but I advise against making it up too much ahead of time.  The chopping, and then the refrigeration of the fruit change the look and texture...Ie...after a while it no longer looks "fresh" but starts to breakdown and get soft.   I will make this again but only allow minimal refrigeration time.  
I used seedless red raspberry preserves and thought that was a nice addition to kind of pull the fruit blend together.  I did not use any extra sugar since my fruit was wonderfully sweet.  I also chose not to use apples since I didn't want the crunch of one fruit mixed into the softness of the other fruits.  Personal preference!
I chose to use the Stacy cinnamon and sugar pita chips but I won't do that again,  They are too thick, and I thought that they overpowered the lightness of the fruit.  I will either make my own chips as the recipe suggests or find another option to dip the fruit.

Display Name:
Siobhan Piercey

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4007107.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I made a few changes after reading some of the reviews...

First, we used Fuji apples instead of Golden Delicious, because they don't brown as quickly. 
I also used 4 oz. raspberries and 4 oz. peaches (instead of just 8 oz. raspberries.) 
I used orange marmalade for the preserves.
I would cut the sugar in half (it was quite sweet.)
For the chips, I simply sprayed both sides of the tortilla, and then I sprinkled cinnamon sugar on top. (I did NOT spray it again.) Then I baked them at 350 degrees for 10 minutes, turning the pan around halfway through baking so that the ones in the back of the oven didn't brown too quickly.
Delicious, but because of the few changes I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. Super yummy!

text:
This is a phenomenal recipe!  So simple and so tasty!  I'm always looking for simple throw-together appetizers to serve at home party get togethers (like 31 Bag parties or Partylite parties).  This fits the bill!  At first I cut the tortillas in wedges before spraying, but then I got wise and followed the other reviewers suggestions and sprayed both sides of the whole tortilla with cooking spray, then dredged both sides in cinnamon-sugar.  I put my cinnamon sugar in a pie pan and that worked really well for dredging the tortillas.  I found that 8-9 minutes was the perfect timing for the chips.  The salsa was delish too!  I didn't add any sugar and used my homemade strawberry jam as the preserves.  My kids especially loved this dish!  It's definitely a keeper!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! I made this tonight. Having read through a lot of the reviews to see what other people had done, I also left out the sugar, and next time, I'll make the chips either with very little or no sugar, too. The fruit is sweet enough on its own. 

I used raspberries, strawberries, blueberries, mango, golden delicious apples, and kiwi, and a large tablespoon of apricot preserves (yeah, I didn't measure... just scooped some out of the jar with a regular tablespoon).  I chopped the apples last after having squeezed a lime half over the cutting board, and kept squeezing lime over the apples as I chopped. And then when everything was mixed, I squeezed all the juice left in the lime halves over the bowl, and next time, will use two limes, and might omit the preserves.

Mango is really good in this, and mint would be a great addition, too. I was too hungry to run outside to pick some tonight; I just wanted to sit down with a bowl of this in one hand and chips in the other and chow down.

This has been one of my go-to summer recipes for entertaining since I discovered it here several years ago. It is a real crowd pleaser yet is usually something your guests have never tried before. It is also a very forgiving recipe in that you can utilize pretty much any fruit you have available. I agree with other reviewers in that the fruit is best cut fairly small so that it still has texture but is easy to dip.

text:
I agree with others who say it's a bit sweet, but I would definitely make it again! I made it for a Valentine's Day Party and used a heart shaped cookie cutter to make the cinnamon chips shaped like hearts. I used raspberry preserves.  While I cut the apples, I had a bowl filled with 1/2 orange juice and half water nearby and soaked them for a few minutes to prevent browning.  Overall it's delicious, simple, and an inexpensive way to bring fruit to a party!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was sooo good!  We made it for a baby shower and only put a tiny bit of brown sugar (no white sugar) and it was perfect.  Also, we made it the night before and the shower was at 2 the next afternoon and it was fine.  We followed the reviews and saved the apples and only cut them just before the shower.  We used gala apples and cut them pretty small.  I'm not sure that you would've been able to tell if they were brown with all of the red that was going on in the dish, but it was very pretty and it was so yummy!  I had 3 people ask for the recipe and there were only about 15 people there, so you know it was great. Definitely a keeper for the recipe box!  Oh, and we used apricot jelly.  Didn't have preserves onhand.  The flavor was great (strawberry would've been too much, I think) and it helped give it that salsa texture.

Delicious. I took other suggestions and omitted the sugar from the fruit - it didn't need it. I used Fuji apples, sprinkled with lemon juice, and had no problems with browning. The cinnamon chips were also a big hit. I tried dipping them in the cinnamon sugar and found them tasty by themselves but too sweet with the fruit so the second time around I just sprinkled the tortillas with the cinnamon sugar and it was a perfect combo with the fruit.

This was a pretty good recipe, although probably not one I will make again. LOVED the chips, did what most recommended and sprayed both sides with Pam first. I also used a pizza cutter to slice the tortillas, which made things easier.  The salsa, was ok.  I used raspberry preserves, and added mango, but that made it too mushy.  The salsa was runny and way too sweet. I should've followed the advice of other readers and omitted the sugar, but wanted to try it first with it. I will definitely make the chips again, but I doubt I'll make the salsa.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
First, let me say the chips were excellent.  I took the idea of spraying the whole tortilla on both sides, sprinkling with a generous amount of sugar and cinnamon, baking about 9 min, then cutting it into triangles.  Everyone loved them.  Second, the fruit salsa left a bit to be desired.  My grocery store didnt have all the fruits; I diced up strawberries, blueberries, and Fuji apples (as recommended by a reviewer) and apricot preserves (also recommended).  Didnt add extra sugar to the fruit (as recommended) because I didnt want it mushy.  It was anyway.  Maybe a sugar free preserve would help?  Everyone liked it enough to eat it, but they werent wild about it.  The colors were good - red, white, and blue - for Memorial Day.  Would make the chips again, but probably not the salsa.  Would probably try a different recipe.  Thanks, though!

This was great. Everyone took a bite, and looked at me funny, as if to say, "I'll eat this because you worked so hard on it, but it's a bit odd...". Awesome recipe- never would have thought of such a simple and delicious concept! Next time will try it without the added sugar, and just the fruit preserves.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Dang it..... We had Easter early and I was short on time. I had to choose to make this or the Snickers Cheesecake (which also got rave reviews.... however this was by FAR my fav!!!)   Use what you have on hand..... you can not go wrong.  I didn't have raspberries so I used a can of Mandarin Oranges.  I used half (100%) Strawberry preserves and half Orange Marmalade..... did NOT add any sugar at all..... didn't need it.  Everyone, including the adults and kids loved it.   As for the tortillas.... put them on parchment paper, spray with the butter spray, sprinkle with cin/sugar.... turn spray other side.... sprinkle and put in oven for about 8 or 9 min.   Don't bother turning... just wait till they are SLIGHTLY crisp and remove. WOW..... GOOOD, GOOOOOD, GOOOOOOOOD!!!

text:
This was AWESOME - just as expected!! I subbed blueberries for raspberries, left out the additional sugar, used grape jelly for preserves, and utilized an onion chopper to make the fruit all more scoopable. For the chips, I sprayed the tortillas, cut with kitchen scissors, and sprinkled one side with cinnamon sugar. I pressed the pieces into mini muffin tins and they came out just right for scooping! The flavor combo is outstanding!

Absolutely loved this. I added just a pinch of brown sugar for flavor, the fruit was sweet enough.  To speed it up, I used an egg slicer to cut everything except the apples. text:
I have made this recipe as is and have customized it to include different fruits (mango, blueberries, etc.). The great thing about this recipe is that it never goes wrong no matter how you make it, suggesting that the fruits and sugars are in good proportion. I also really enjoy the tortilla chips by themselves. I discovered that you can make similar chips with garlic powder, salt, and various herbs to make an excellent dipper for hummus.

text:
I couldn't believe that something so easy can turn out to be so good. I took this to work for an app contest and I won. I used strawberries, apples, kiwi, & peaches. I did not even use a preserve. I chopped and combined the night before with the exception of the apples. This allowed for the flavors to really soak together. Make sure to cook the chips long enough a couple of batches came out a little rubbery and should have been cooked just a tad longer. The bowl was scrapped clean and everyone asked for the recipe. I also included cool whip on the side for people to top it with. Will defianlty make this summer for a great refreshing app.

This was so so good and loved by all who tried it at my party.  I used as another suggested, 2 peaches (fresh)instead of the blackberries and I used apricot for the preserves. Will be making this one often.....have to wow all my groups!!!!

userID:
1280048
Display Name:
ICIBIU
isPro:

31

139
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great, definitely my new "go to" potluck dish!! I've used all the fruits listed but i've also added: Pineapple, peaches, nectarines & mandarin oranges (only fruit I used the canned version of). Both times I used apricot preserves.  TIPS: I put some ice water and the juice of half a lemon in a bowl and as i chopped the apples I put them in there and drained well at the end. I had no problems with browning and the lemon added a nice little zip. If you have a large group and want to make a little extra without breaking the bank add more apples, they are cheap and add volume. Make sure you make plenty of chips, they go pretty fast (someone dubbed them "churro chips" at my BBQ & the kids all said it was like cinnamon toast crunch) I used two packs of ten and had no leftovers. If you run out of chips, throw the fruit in a pitcher and add some wine, yummy sangria!! Great way to use up the leftovers :) Be prepared to give out the recipe you WILL be asked!!

text:
Fresh and wonderful! Excellent idea--a fun twist on traditional salsa. I had this in my recipe box for YEARS and finally made it yesterday... should NOT have waited! What a hit! I used granny smith apples, kiwi, strawberry, and some blueberries for color. I don't think you need all that extra sugar if your fruit it in season! The preserves are a must though! --I used whole grain pitas and that worked quite nicely. Carefully shook them in a ziplock bag to coat. --For presentation, I used the idea of baking a tortilla over a bowl for 15 minutes...then piled the chips in there. So fun! Will post photos!

text:
My family has been making this recipe every summer but we do it a little different.  Eliminate the use of both brown and white sugar for a healthier recipe.  Add in Mangos,peaches and/or nectarines.  Use any apples you prefer. and use any fruit preserves you have on hand.  The best so far has been Apricot/Pineaple preserves.  Also at teh end squeeze a few limes before mixing to add a little juice and zest as well as keeping the color.

This was such a big hit with my family and so easy!!!  We did make some of the changes other reviewers suggested.  We did switch out the raspberries for frozen peaches.  I used blackberry preserves instead of the suggested orange marmalade.  Also, I used Pam organic olive oil spray instead of the butter sprays & the chips tasted fabulous.  This is a healthier alternative.  Also, I did add the sugar into the fruit, even though other reviewers said it makes more juice.  We actually liked the juice since it was a salsa.

text:
I had no idea how yummy this would be but EVERY time I make it, I get so many compliments on it!  If you're in a hurry and don't have time to make the cinnamon chips, just buy a bag of Stacy's Cinnamon Sugar Pita Chips.  They taste great and make it easier to scoop up the fruit dip.  Very YUMMY!!!

userID:
3296215
Display Name:
Mary Sunshine
