photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best appetizer recipe I've ever made!  I mixed strawberry and appricot preserves, which was a great combination.  For the chips, I mixed cinnamon and sugar in a large ziploc bag (about 1 Tblsp. cinnamon to 1 cup sugar).  I cut the tortillas with a pizza cutter, sprayed a plate with the butter flavored pam and laid the pieces of tortilla on the plate.  Then I sprayed the tops of the tortilla pieces, put them in the ziploc bag, and shook them in the sugar/cinnamon mixture.  I transferred them to a foil-lined cookie sheet, and they cooked up nicely in about 11 minutes in my oven.  My family loved this recipe.  It will definitely be a frequently used appetizer at our house!

text:
Yummy! I think this recipe adapts easily. I couldn't find raspberries so I substituted frozen peaches. I also used oreange marmalade per another reviewer's suggestion. I still used the sugars, but I served it not longer after I made it. I chopped the peaches when they were partially thawed and added them to the mix. Having the peaches still frozen kept the salsa cold on the counter for about 45 minutes. I made the chips the day before the party and they kept well in a sealed container. Guests liked this alot.

region:

country:
None
text:
This is amazingly good, and very flexible.  Made this for a party with a "bring a salsa" theme, and it was the favorite by far.  I have varied the fruits based on what looks good that day at the market, and it works every time.  The cinnamon chips take this over the top and I wouldn't serve it with any other kind of chips, but you can buy sweet chips at the store if you are pressed for time.  This makes a lot of liquid as it sits, and my sis-in-law loves to stir it up and put leftovers on pound cake or angel food...  and I have to agree that it's a tasty way to finish this off!  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
Delicious! I used strawberries, granny smith appels, peaches, kiwi, and green seedless grapes- all fresh. Chopping all the fruit of course was a bit tedious but dont be discouraged- it was well worth the effort. I didnt any any perserves- it was fine without it. I ended up not putting any sugar on the tortillas before baking them because I realized after the first batch that the combination of sweet fruit and sweet chips was just a bit too much. Just a personal preference I think. But overall very good.

I made this for a girls night and it was just okay. I thought it was going to be "amazing", but really it's just chopped up fruit served with pita chips. Also, the fruit gets more and more watery as it sits there, so after an hour or so be prepared that its VERY runny and can be quite messy. It would actually be better if served as a dessert, such as an ice-cream topping, but not so great as an app.

text:
So fabulous!!! I wanted to bring something different next time the girls got together and this was the winner! It went over fantastic, all loved it, although I let it refridgerate overnight and it was quite runny. The next time I made it I did make some slight variations - such as only using 1 apple and only 1 tbsp of preserves to reduce the liquidity, added some diced mango. Also, I melted 2 tbsp of butter with the brown sugar in the microwave and coated the chips before baking. They turned out soft and brown...lovely. Overall, a huge hit! I will continue to whip this up when we're in the mood for something fun and fruity!!! Thanks for sharing :)

text:
YUMMY! I love that you can make it with any fruit combination - I used apples, pineapple, kiwi, and strawberries! It was incredible. I took the other reviewer's advice for the chips and just sprayed both sides of the tortilla with pam, sliced it in about 12 pieces, and threw the pieces into a gallon bag with the cinnamon sugar mixture. One tip: Don't cook the chips too long! I thought I had to cook them until they were a little hard, but then they were overdone. The next batch I cooked until they were barely golden brown, took them out of the oven and they continued to harden on their own. They turned out perfect.

This recipe looks so simple--I couldn't believe it would turn out as good as it did. I made it for our family dinner last Friday and my daughter-in-law has already made 2 more batches by request--the kids wanted more chips on the weekend & a neighbor tasted it & told her to bring some along for 4th of July.
It's easy to find the way you like to do the chips best--I sprayed, sugared, sprayed again and THEN cut the tortillas. Store bought would be OK, but not as good as making these yourself.

I'll add my 5 stars to the other 1800 ratings for this recipe.  Made it according to the recipe - with the exception of adding diced banana as well - it was wonderful...not at all runny as some others found...I think the key may be in how you dice the fruit - I would imagine using a food processor might overdo it and cause it to be runny.  One of the great things about the recipe is that you can add whatever your favorite fruit is and it's still delicious! I'll be making this often Thanks for sharing.

2158718
Display Name:
Michon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a luncheon and it was an absolute HIT!  The Golden Delicious apples (GDA's) worked fine for me and hadn't turned brown.  I first chopped the Kiwi, then with the Kiwi still on the counter/cutting board, cut up the GDA's.  Periodically I mixed the apples and Kiwi together while chopping the apples such that the juices of the Kiwi (similar to Lemons/Limes) can prevent them from turning brown.  The flesh brightness maintained itself and the preserving properties of the preserves also lent to this.  (II).  For the Cinnamon Chip - I placed the cinnamon sugar in a wide-mouthed bowl (mixing sized perhaps).  I sprayed both sides of the tortillas as I stacked/piled them in the same manner they were packaged.  Then I cut the stack/pile into the wedges.  I even stacked some of the stacks.  I peeled each wedged and dredged and pinched it around the sugar (both sides) for coverage then placed it in the pan, conveniently close.  Kept 'em moist, close, non-sticky/messy and simple.  

Thanks!

text:
This is a wonderfull recipe. It was simple and delicious! Everyone loved it. A tip for some of you guys: If you dont want the apples to brown add a teaspoon of lemon juice to them. You dont have to add as much sugar as the recipe asks for. Just a little bit of the sugar draws out the juices of the fruit.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have been wanting to make this salsa for sooo long... I finally made it with some help from the reviews, I used 1 carton of Strawberries, 2 Necterines, 3 Kiwis, and 2 Fugi apples. Before I put the apples into the bowl I squeezed half of a lemon on them, so they wouldn't brown. Then mixed the fruit with 2 Tbsp. Strawberry Preseves. No added sugar Tip: the more you mix, the juicier the fruit gets. Then instead of flour tortillas, I used whole wheat pitas,glazed with butter, and sprinkled with cinnamon,cut them in 4's and baked them in the oven, until they were brown. OMG!!! I brought them for Easter dinner, I got so many compliments. Everyone love it. Not only is is pritty and delicious, It's guiltless, too. I will be making this again. Thanks AR.

text:
Decided to try this recipe when I was looking for a healthy appitizer to take with me to a party.  Well, everyone loved it and gobbled it down (and asked for the recipe).  Made it tonight for the second time and my picky boyfriend (who was very iffy about it before trying it - he's not too crazy about fruit) loved it.

I did change the recipe a fair amount though.  I diced 1 green apple, 1 mango and ~8 strawberries.  Mixed them together with 1 tblsp raspberry jam and 2 tblsp reduced sugar black cherry compote.  I didn't add any sugar into the mixture, and it was definitely sweet (and juicy) enough, even with low sugar jams.

For the chips, I used only 5 whole wheat tortillas (this was a better ratio of fruit to chips then the 10 I used the first time).  I mixed splenda and cinnamon together in a ziplock bag and then tossed the (sprayed) chips in the bag with the sugar mixture.

YUM!

text:
Made this for Super Bowl party.  Took the advise of some reviews about the extra juice and sweetnes issue.  I used frozen peaches instead raspberries and a different type of apple, mainly because that is what I had on hand.  I turned out pretty good.  The next weekend I  served it with pieces of cinnamon graham crakers.  They seem to go well together.  Also, I froze the left overs (which I held separate in the fridge for refills) and served it the next weekend over a mixture of cream cheese, butter, sugar, vanilla (sort of like a cream cheese danish filling).  It was fabulous.  Everyone seemed to like it, however some of the guys wished I had warned them about the sweetness, because they were expecting a traditional type salsa.  So, next time I will split a piece of whole fruit and rest it on the side of the bowl.  Maybe that will give a clue.  I will be making this many times in the future, especially in the summer!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This fruit salsa was so easy and simply delicious! I followed the recipe exactly except for omitting both the white sugar and the brown sugar, as other reviewers had suggested. The fruit and the preserves were definitely sweet enough without the added sugar, plus the salsa kept it's consistency and did not water. I was going to make it even easier by buying the cinnamon chips, but I could not find them in my grocery store. And I am very happy that I didn't, because the 'homemade' chips were the best part - great crunch and light sweetness. I took the advice of another reviewer and used a pizza cutter to cut the butter sprayed torillas into 8 wedges each, and then placed each one in the cinnamon/sugar bowl to coat one side and arranged them on the baking sheet with the sugar side up. This was less messy than sprinkling on the sugar mix. This appetizer/dessert also looks great arranged on a dish. I brought it to a small (20 people) party recently and EVERY person wanted the recipe. It's a versatile recipe that can be served any time of the year - thanks so much for the great dish!

Made this weekend and it was a hit!  Took some advice from other reviewers and made the following changes.  I brushed the tortillas with melted butter and sprinkled with the cinnamon sugar, then baked for 11 min.  30 sec. and they were nice and crisp. I did use frozen raspberries and frozen blueberries, but i drained then for awhile before i added them.  I also put my chopped apples in water and lemon juice while i made the salsa and they did not brown.  I had some   cinnamon chips left over and they are like cookies...we love them!
Thanks...can't wait for summer fresh fruit.

text:
this recipe is super yummy!
changes i made: i added a package of cream cheese and a handfull of mini marshmellows, melted, to the mixture, creating an AWESOME fruity-cheesecake taste. i omitted the strawberries but used fresh strawberry preserves. i did one batch with Pink Lady apples, then another batch with Fuji apples. The Pink Ladies held up better, in color and in crispness. 
this recipe isnt as good after sitting for 2 days. its still yummy but the apples arent as crisp and everything else just seems mushy. i sliced and toasted 8 tortillas worth of chips but that wasnt enough. i'd go for 10 or 12 next time.

text:
this was so freaking good. i've had the link to the recipe on my favorites for a while, but i haven't had the resources to buy $20 worth of fruit until now. (i doubled the recipe, which i would definitely recommend!)

i didn't add any of the sugar or the preserves because it was already really sweet. i also substituted pineapple for kiwi since my boyfriend is allergic to them. the pineapple made it nice and tart/sweet. someone on here suggested an egg slicer to cut up the fruit, and that worked really well! i also used Fuji apples and they didn't brown at all. this was SO good. i'm definitely making this once every couple of weeks. i think it would also be good served with ice cream (maybe Breyer's Vanilla Bean?).

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Over the 4th of July holiday, I tried this recipe out on 4 different groups of people. It was a hit with every group. The first time, I made it exactly by the way it states, using rasberry preserves, and it was great. The second time, I used blackberrys instead of rasberries and used apricot preserves, and it was even better! Ok, hints to make this easier. Go to WallMart and buy Black and Deckers 10.00 chopper. It cut prep time down to about 15 minutes. Also, since the recipe does come out soupy, I let it sit in a strainer for 15 minutes, and that took care of alot of fluid. One last thing, add whatever nuts you want, it makes it even better. I used walnuts, and almonds. I also served it with the little waffle cups, people loved it! The cinnamon chips were easy to make, and using the muffing tin was a good idea.
I will be making this again.

text:
After looking through some reviews I made the following changes: no sugar with the fruit, peach fruit preserves. blackberries instead of raspberries (for color), golden apples added last to prevent browning, sprayed both sides of the tortilla/cut with a pizza knife, dredged in cinnamon sugar. 

Overall this turned out pretty well. Everyone seemed to like it, but no one was jumping for joy (like I had expected from the reviews). I can't hold it aganist the receipe since I did make changes, and I will for sure make this again. 

My only problem was the salsa was a little juicy. The chips were great and I'll use those for other recipes!

text:
I made this recipe for a party, and people raved over it!  I followed the recipe mostly as written, using Granny Smith apples and blackberries instead of raspberries.  However, when I made the cinnamon chips, I did not use butter spray, which gives me the creeps, but I brushed melted butter over the top of each tortilla and then sprinkled the cinnamon sugar over the top.  I did not brush butter over a second time.  Also, be sure to watch the chips carefully in then oven.  I found that they were done a minute or two earlier than the prescribed 8 min.

text:
Reading the recipe, I couldn't imagine how it could possibly be as fantastic as the review say.  It looks too easy.  There aren't may things in it.  Well, I've got to agree that this is 100% an example of the sum being more than the parts.  I made this three times the first week.  This is just great!  Everyone at the party I tried it out on loved it and wanted more.  I made enough for 4 times the number of people there and there was NOTHING left.  You won't be disappointed.
I did leave out the sugar and used blueberries instead of raspberries, but I did use raspberry jam for that taste.  I also used apple slices that I'd frozen from last apple season so I did have to drain some sauce off to keep it from being too wet. I think the frosty apples were easier to chop and made the salsa nice and cool, great for summer!  My 5 year old loved the chips all by themselves.

city:

country:

text:
Wow, this was fantastic! I prepared the salsa a day ahead of time adding everything except the apples and sugars. I used one granny smith apple and one fiji apple. I also added peaches to the recipe. About an hour before serving I mixed in the sugars and apples, then placed the salsa in the fridge. For the chips, I sliced the tortillas with a pizza cutter and coated each piece with the spray. I then placed the pieces into a container with the cinnamon sugar mixture and just shook it until they were all covered. I then cooked the tortillas in a muffin pan to make little bowls out of them. It worked out perfectly. I would like to try it again with a mini muffin pan. I cooked them for 10 minutes and they all turned out perfectly. I made 36 scoops with the tortillas and had exactly enough to use up all of the chips and salsa. This was the biggest hit and I am so excited to make it again! Thanks for the wonderful recipe.

country:
None
text:
I made this a few weeks ago when we had several families over and I was looking for a kid-friendly appetizer. Everyone loved it! My daughters keep asking me to make it again and again. I didn't like the method of placing the tortilla triangles in a ziplock bag with sugar/cinnamon as they came out too sweet and not quite as crisp. I sort of dredge them in the sugar/cinnamon and, thus, can control the amount going on each. I ended up with frozen raspberries and they added so much taste to the salsa. Wonderful, wonderful!

text:
I love this recipe and so does everyone I make it for. I follow the directions and it turns out wonderful everytime! When I bake the tortillas I cut them into wedges with a pizza cutter and arrange them in muffin pans. If you push them down in the pan or align them in the curve of the muffin pan it gives the chips the curved look. I bake the chips until they are brown which may take a little longer than 8 to 10 minutes. 
Overall this is a great easy recipe that everyone who enjoys fruit will love!

text:
We just finished eating this as a precursor to our Sunday meal.  Made the fruit salsa according to the recipe sans brown sugar and most of the white sugar (just threw in a bit).  Was generous with the raspberries (probably 9 oz.).  The problem we had were the chips.  Made them according to the recipe but couldn't get the texture right. I'm still giving it a five.  If someone has tips for how to get crispy chips that would be great.  I saw someone toasted them (I think BEFORE the oven) but I was worried they'd be too cooked.  Ours were pretty much the consistancy of really stale tortilla.  We used WHEAT tortilla... perhaps that was the issue.  Ended up using cinammon graham crackers instead -- yummy!  We'll both be taking this to work for the week!

text:
The fruit salsa is amazingly good and the cinnamon chips really impressed family/friends.  You can even make this recipe low sugar by using Splenda in the salsa and on the cinnamon chips.  You can also use whole wheat tortillas to make this recipe even more healthy.  If using Splenda and whole wheat tortillas, use a light hand when sprinkling the tortillas and bake them in the lower end of the time range.  

A fabulous (and healthy!) recipe!

text:
This was pretty good, but I made a few changes.  Instead of apples, I used 4 just ripe (but firm) nectarines.  I used 3/4 pound strawberries (too many overpower the taste of the other fruits).  I also used about 1/2 the sugar that is called for, and I used apricot preserves.  It was a hit at a superbowl party, and the healthiest thing there :)  Leftover fruit salsa can be put in a dessert dish and topped with whipped cream.  Next time I may add some Mango.

text:
I'm not quite sure what all the rave is over this appetizer.  I agree that it tastes fresh, sweet, but it's just not as fantastic as I was expecting.  It definitely tastes as if it's missing something.  I had someone suggest adding liqueur or even vodka.  Maybe a "kick" is what it needs.  I did enjoy the cinnamon chips and might use them with another dish, but I'm not sure if this is one I'll make again.  Rather boring taste if you like bringing exciting things to gatherings.  Other things to keep in mind:  the expense of these items can really add up; I suggest only preparing approximately 1 1/2 cups cinnamon sugar; I agree the versatility of this dish is outstanding!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/380369.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent.
The only thing I would do different is leave out fruit that you can't find fresh. Raspberries were super expensive, so I bought them frozen. I chopped up my strawberries, kiwi and apple and it looked so pretty in the bowl. The raspberries, thawed, were mushy and disgusting. So I mixed some of the mushy raspberries with the jam. It still tasted great, but I think it would have looked prettier (instead of a big bowl of jam) if I had left out the raspberries - and you wouldn't have even noticed if I had.
The cinnamon chips were incredibly easy to make - much to my relief. I will certainly be doing this recipe again, simply because those chips were so easy to make. 
I doubled up the recipe for a bridal shower (19 guests) and I really didn't have to. There's plenty for 19 people in one batch if you are serving other food.

text:
This is fantastic!  I have made it twice this week and both times everyone has loved it!!  I changed the fruits a bit (I'm not fond of kiwi).  I used fresh pineapple, strawberries, apples, and a few marchino cherries.  I used my food processor and can't imagine cutting all that fruit without it.  Cut the fruit up into big chunks, dump it in the food processor and pulse a few times until blended and cut up.  It's amazing!  The chips took a bit more time.  Tho, they were worth it.  Very yummy!  :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe sounded unique and tasty and I decided to make it for a party we had last night.  Of the many items served, the salsa and chips received the most raving reviews.  

Making the salsa is straightforward but labor-intensive, in that there is a lot of chopping involved.  The chips were a little more difficult and time-consuming.  I was doubling the recipe, and I spent about 90 minutes preparing and baking the tortilla chips.  The chip-making process was a bit messy, too.  In the end, all the labor was worth it.  The chips and salsa are like nothing you've ever had!  

The only thing I will do differently next time is use smaller tortillas to get a more uniform sized chip; I found the wedges from the 10" tortilla to be too long and awkward.

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for our office 4th of July party.  Talk about a hit!  All the women and some of the men wanted the recipe.  It was really easy to make, however it was a bit time consuming.  The chopping wasn't so bad, but the chips took a while.  It was well worth the time!  I made it the night before and let it sit in the fridge.  It was very juicy the next morning, so if you don't like a "juicy salsa" you need to serve shortly after making.  Personally, I loved the juices.  Makes for a great topping for ice cream, pancakes, waffles & crepes!  The chips are a meal in themselves and go great with the salsa.  A nice cool change from the same old boring appetizers!  I highly recommend!!! Just remember to set aside extra time for the chips!

text:
Excellent Recipe!  I just served it this past Saturday for my son's 9th Birthday party and there was very little left.  I doubled the recipe (because I was serving 50 people) and I think there was only a cup leftover.  Also, when doubling you really only need 3 Tablespoons of Preserves especially if you make it a day ahead of time.  Makes a ton of juice if you leave overnight before serving (The kids used the juice on their ice cream after dinner).  And for the Cinnamon Chips.........They were PERFECT!!!!  Made these about 2 days in advance and sealed in an airtight container.(They extremely crispy).  Thanks to the individuals who posted a review with the pizza cutter idea.....IT WORKED GREAT!!!

This fruit salsa was amazing!  I served it to a party of 30 guests, and every person there loved it!  (I ended up having to have recipe cards printed up!)  Cutting the fruit was the time consuming part, but it was incredibly easy to make, and well worth the effort.  I substituted blueberries for raspberries and plum for the kiwi and used a pear preserve as the base. I will DEFINATELY do this again!!!

text:
Delicious!  I served it at a small party I had and everyone loved it and asked for the recipe.  Since some of the fruit was out of season and not very sweet, I mixed together strawberries, blueberries and raspberries with some white sugar and refrigerated it overnight.  I added the rest of the ingredients the next day, but cut the white sugar in half.  The chips took a little time to make, but were worth it.  This would taste even better with a little whipped cream on top or as an ice cream topping.  Thanks for sharing!!

If I made this again I would experiment with the chips and come up with something different, perhaps something crunchier. I had lots of leftover, and it did stay fresh tasting until the next day.

text:
I made this exactly as is and my chips were soft, soggy. I cooked another batch longer and got crispy chips but it was difficult to eat. The salsa was tasty and the idea is great.  I'll try again with  some adjustments, chips at a higher temp and flipping the chips, or cook with a deep fryer to get crisp. Fruit cut in tiny pieces in a viscous syrup might be the key to keeping it on the chip all the way to the mouth.

text:
This was a big hit at my sorority meeting last night.  I used kiwi, apples, peaches, strawberries and raspberries for the fruit and orange marmalade and peach preserves to thicken and hold it together.  I cut the fruit VERY small, in fact some I put in my small electric food chopper for a few seconds.   It was really easy to scoop these smaller pieces onto the chips.  I didn't add any sugar to the fruit, since the marmalade was sweet.  No one seemed to think it needed to be any sweeter.  The chips added enough sugar to the overall taste.  I will definitely make this again, maybe even try different fruits.

text:
Great, great recipe.  This has been a hit with everyone I've served it to.  I didn't add any white sugar and added only half of the brown sugar to the fruit and it is still plenty sweet.  I think the sugar in the preserves is more than enough.  Next time I make it, I will even try it without adding any sugar at all to the fruit.  The chips are great too - I've been using whole wheat tortillas, butter Pam, and dredging both sides in the sugar/cinnamon mix (1 cup sugar + 1 tsp cinnamon) - they taste great.  I've been adding the leftover fruit salsa to my cereal in the morning - there's a lot you can do with this recipe.

text:
Delicious recipe! Local market didn't have fresh raspberries so I used raspberry preserves as my choice of preserve. Be careful not to chop/dice the fruits up too small b/c it will become very runny. (Did that the first time around but it doesn't affect the taste- was great both times!) Also, I chose to coat both sides of my chips w/ cinnamon sugar. These were a big hit- I had people eating just the chips by themselves. If your oven runs hot keep an eye on them! Definitely worth a try, you won't regret it!

text:
I finally made this recipe & it was a great success. It tasted so fresh. It was nice to bring something different to a party. The combination of fruits can be tailored to your likes/dislikes. I used all the suggested fruits plus Braeburn apple, fresh pineapple, blueberries, blackberries & canned mandarin oranges. I used a "Vidalia Chop Wizard" to cut up the apples , pineapple.& strawberries.  It worked really well and chopped everything very uniformly. I rough chopped the blackberries & oranges. For the chips I lightly brushed w/melted butter, stacked 3 or 4 & cut into wedges. Then I shook in a bag w/sugar & cinnamon.  I think they were the real star. Everyone was munching & commenting on how good they were. I  purposely went light on the sugar in the fruit because the chips are sweet. Thanks for a great recipe.

This was amazing.  Even my somewhat anti-fruit brother loved it.  I didn't add the brown or white sugar.  I don't think it needs it.  I used strawberry preserves.  I tripled the cinnamon chips and set up an assembly line to make it go faster. text:
Hit of the party!  We used Granny Smith apples instead of the Golden Delicious, added blackberries, cut back on the white and brown sugar and used Apricot preserves...YUM!    We also used low-carb tortillas, which I don't know if I'd try again.  They needed to bake about twice as long as the recipes recommends and they still don't firm up as much as the regular tortillas probably do.  However, they still tasted fine and it was nice to know they were a little healthier.  On the flip side of that- we discovered that the cinnamon and sugar really makes the chips, so don't be stingy- dump it on!  ENJOY!

THIS WAS AMAZE-BALLS!   I used strawberry preservatives, fuji apples, blueberries (because I hate raspberries), and strawberries. This recipe was a huge hit with men, women, teens, and children. I could not find raspberries, ao I substitued with blue berries.   I generously added cilantro and substituted sugar with splenda and the brown sugar with splenda brown sugar mix.  I also used natural preserves, no sugar added. I made it as an appetizer, but it followed us to the table as a wonderful compliment to the ham and pork loin.  Every single person asked for the recipe and some called within a few days to say they had already made it.    It is on our menu for Super Bowl Sunday!

text:
Very good!!! Last time I made this, I used two bags of frozen fruit instead of the expensive and out of season fresh fruit (one was a berry blend - blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, strawberries; the other was peaches, mangos, grapes, and honeydew melon), I omitted all of the sugar, and I used 3 tablespoons of sugar free honey instead of fruit preserves.   I cut the tortillas up using seasonal cookie cutters, and I dipped them in melted butter, then lightly patted each side with a mix of 1 cup Splenda sugar substitute and 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon. This was VERY good and was diabetic friendly! A huge hit at our family party!!

text:
Absolutely delicious! However, I don't add any sugar at all, and I use blackberry preserves as the matrix to hold it all together. It gives the salsa a darker color, but I love the flavor. I like to add bananas to the mix, and I make light work of chopping all the fruits by using my collard chopper (the serrated round tool with the wooden handle). The chips are fantastic as well! I make this for a lot of large get-togethers, and I come home with an empty bowl nearly every time.

text:
This is super yummy!  It is a hit everytime I make it, and I always have to give the recipe out!  I make it almost as directed.  A few changes are, I don't add the preserves all the time (if I have it I do) I don't really notice much of a difference with it.  Also I use an 8 inch tortilla, and I cut them with a pizza cutter, place them on the pan, spray them, then add the cinnamon and sugar, I think it's much easier this way.  Enjoy!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-12-18T07:33:42.773
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4158911
Display Name:
waynefannon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
167
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We tried this out when my wife and I went down to my parents' house to visit. It was a huge hit! So much that my folks even decided to make it a few weeks later as an hors d'oeuvre before our big family Thanksgiving dinner. One thing I tried the first time was chopping all the fruit using a food processor. It saved us time, but everything ended up looking pureed. (It still tasted wonderful.) The second time we made it, we chopped the fruit by hand and it looked much more appetizing, and had the same great flavor. We melted butter to brush over the tortillas before sprinkling on the cinnamon and sugar. It was a piece of cake!  One caution I can give to anyone trying this is to make sure the tortillas stay in the oven until they're somewhat crispy. We took out one batch a little too early and while they were much more firm than raw tortilla, they were a little to flimsy to hold a big pile of fruit salsa.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great!  I personally make a "poor man's" version.  I leave out the raspberries and kiwis, but add in grapes.  You don't miss them and makes this recipe much more affordable.    Also, rather than chop up all the fruit, I toss them in the blender and pulse until the consistency is about right.  Saves a lot of headaches!  AND, rather than make the chips, I use regular tortilla chips, spray with cooking spray, sprinkle with cinnamon and sugar, then put in a 350 oven for a few minutes.  Take them out, stir, and repeat until the chips have enough sugar and cinnamon for your tastes.

3653812
Display Name:
i. heart. food.
isPro:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The chips were delicious! For the apples, I used Fuji apples and put a squirt of lemon juice on them to keep from browning and this recipe does NOT need any extra sugar.  I followed advice of other reviewers and sprayed the tortillas with spray butter, sprinkled cinnamon sugar over each side, then cut with a pizza cutter.  Placing the tortillas on a cooling rack in the bottom of the sink while spraying and sprinkling makes a HUGE difference in clean up.  The more sugar in your cinnamon/sugar mix, the crispier your chips will be (I found that too much cinnamon makes them a tad chewier).  My eaters kept saying the tasted like churros - YUM!

country:
None
text:
what a great way to get fruit on the table!  this recipe is very flexable.  you could substitute many different fruits and it would still taste good.  i did leave out the sugars, though, with fresh fruit.  you may need a little with not-so-fresh fruit.  my only complaint is that the recipe does not tell you how to mix the cinnamon and sugar.  i had to read that in another review.  and the method of cin/sugar distribution on the tortillas is a bit time consuming.  i used the suggestion of the ziplock bag method, and that worked great!  my 13 year old daughter did that part, and she had no problems with it.  if you are baking the tortilla on a stone pan, it will take a couple of minutes longer for the chips to get krispy.

country:

text:
Everyone loved this salsa! I made it the night before going to my dads for Father's Day.  I used strawberries, kiwis, raspberries, and a gala apple.  To cut down on sugar (diabetic) I used Splenda and the juice of half a lemon to keep the apple from turning brown.  The next day I made the chips as per directions.  For some reason my chips were tough.  I followed the instructions but my chips were hard to chew.  They tasted good just tough.  I don't know if it was the flour tortillas or me but it's the reason for four stars instead of five.  The fruit salsa is a solid five stars.

text:
Really delicious! I used apricot preserves and added peaches. For the chips, I highly recommend spraying the tortillas on both sides with butter flavor cooking spray and then coating with cinnamon sugar mixture. (I do this on some wax paper to cut back on the mess.) Stack the tortillas, then cut them into triangles. This was a huge hit with my friends and family!

text:
This is an amazing dish.  The trick is to get all of the fruit a uniform size, best if it is all very small pieces.  I have made this several times and found that plums, raspberries, cherries, strawberries, grapes & apples work the best other fruits are either too mushy of overpowering.  I serve this with the Carla's Fruit Dip recipe.

text:
Very tasty. I made this for a BBQ and it was a huge hit. I used granny smith apples, blueberries, kiwi, strawberries and raspberries. For the preserves I used apricot. Next I might try the pineapple preserves. I also omitted the white sugar and used only brown, and sometimes I even use honey. I made my tortilla chips out of wheat tortillas and I have also used trader joe's cinnamon sugar pita chips. Both are great!

text:
I have made this recipe so many times and everyone raves about it.  It is especially good in the summertime.  I do not add the brown sugar because I think it makes it a bit too sweet.  I also dice all of the fruit the same size because it makes it look nicer.  I always use real melted butter for the tortillas and not the spray because everything is better with real butter.  It coats the tortillas better too. Now when I bring it to a holiday or a party, I print a few copies of the recipe out because I know that everyone will be asking for it.

text:
I got tons of compliments on both the dip and the cinnamon chips. Both were pretty easy to make. I put all the fruit into my food processor and then stirred in strawberry jam after. It was runnier than in the photo shown that way (and I had a lot extra - I would recommend tripling the amount of chips because they go fast) but very delicious. For the chips, I mixed the cinnamon and sugar in a bowl, sprayed the chips with cooking spray and dropped them into the mix. Very easy and a hit!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this so many times now.  Every time, I get asked for the recipe and I never have any leftovers.  I cut back a little on the sugar.  I also prefer apricot jam.  Really it all mixes together and nobody can tell which jam you used anyhow.  For the chips, I spray an entire tortilla, sprinkle it with the cinnamon and sugar and repeat for each, stacking them as I go.  Once I have a stack, I just cut them with a knife.  Saves lots of time.  Also, because they bake so flat, I've learned to lay them around the edge of a cookie sheet so they're more scoopable.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars because I'm going to eat it all, but somehow it isn't really a 5-star recipe for me personally. I did change the fruits in it quite a bit though, so maybe that's the problem. I used pluots, black plums, nectarines, & frozen mixed berries. The tortilla chips are very tasty, and I will probably make those again just to snack on, but the fruit just wasn't as tasty as the chips. We decided it was a waste of tasty chips to put that fruit on them and I'm going to turn that salsa into a cobbler :) All in all this recipe was a success for me because it did produce food we're going to eat, and because it did produce food I would serve to company--just not food I would slave over again for just me and my husband!

text:
This is a fantastic recipe! The reason why I gave it 4 stars is because I changed quite a bit of it. I think the recipe gives you a great idea to run with. I used fresh plums, mango, Fuji apple, strawberries and blackberries. I mixed it with Tayberry jam and substituted the additional sugar for honey. It was fantastic. As for the cinnamon chips, they were great and pair perfectly with the fruit salsa. I sprayed both sides of the tortilla then tossed the tortilla in a large plastic bag with the cinnamon sugar mixture and laid it out onto a baking sheet. Turned out great!

text:
This was amazing - I have made it twice now. Agree with others - no additional sugar is necessary on top of the fruit as it makes it liquidy. I just added the perserves and it was delicious. Also, like others - I found it easier (and for more coverage) to cut the tortillas in 8ths, spray with pam on both sides and then dredge them with the sugar/cinnamon mixture with no additional pam on top. They crisp up just fine. I upped the temp just a tad and monitored for crispness. Thsi is truly a hit.

text:
I used frozen peaches, pinnapple tidbits (which I also chopped) instead of the rasberries.  After making batches of the chips, I learned that the dark-coated baking sheets require the chips baking time to be 9 minutes and light ones 10 minutes.  I also added 2 tablespoons of lemon juice, cinnamon, and nutmeg.

text:
I loved this recipe! I made this for Christmas Eve at my in-laws and it was a big hit -- the flavors in the dip were great.  I used 2 tsp. of Smuckers' Sweet Orange Marmalade and 1 tsp. of Apricot preserves along with an 8 oz. bag of frozen berries (strawberries, raspberries, blueberries, and blackberries) that I bought at Walmart for less than $3!  Then I added 1/2 a bag of frozen peaches and 1 Fuji apple -- it ended up being delicious! Oh, and I kept the sugar in the recipe and it did make it a little runny but the flavor was wonderful.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I had to alter the recipe a bit due to the unavailability of fruit in the winter season in Nebraska. I used 1 bag of frozen berry blend (strawberries, cherries, blackberries, raspberries, and blueberries), 2 braeburn apples, 1 bartlett pear, apricot preservers, and the rest the same as the recipe. I was surprised at the large amount that it made. I saved half and used it with yogurt, ice, and fruit juice in smoothies. It was fabulous both ways. I will make this again!

text:
This was soooo delish!!!!!! It really is versatile too.  I made mine with strawberries, kiwi, a pear, nectarines (firm, not soft ones), pink lady apples, and blueberries.  I used raspberry preserves and the sugars listed.  I took this to a family reunion, and it was a hit!!!!! I can't wait to make this again, and  this is a wonderful way for any adult or child to get their fruit intake.  I made the chips the night before, and they were still crisp the next afternoon.  I was sooo scared to make this,and be disappointed, but disappointed I was not.  Thanx for an awesome recipe... oh yeah, cut your fruit by hand, not with a chopper.  It stays more firm this way.  Don't make this if you are crimped for time, it really is time consuming.

Ecellent recipe-as stated in previous reviews, I sprayed both sides of each tortilla with PAM, cut them with a pizza cutter into wedges, then coated them with cinnamon by shaking them in a ziplock bag.  I doubled the chip recipe, but not the salsa as most people would eat the chips without the salsa.  My salsa got a little runny during the party, so I ended up straining out the liquid out (saved it for ice cream topping--mmm).  I used kiwi, strawberries, gala apples and raspberries.  I think I will try adding peaches next time I make it as suggested by other reviewers.

Awesome!  I used butter-flavored spray on one side of the tortilla, sugared it, cut with pizza cutter, turned the pieces over onto a foil covered cookie sheet,then sprayed & sugared the second side.  10 min at 350, no more than that or they were overcooked.  Perfect!  I had no trouble with browning fruit, i added lemon juice to my apple and banana pieces.  I also omitted the raspberry (didnt have any on hand).  Color was perfect, everyone raved - thank you!

Served it for a jewelry party, and got lots of compliments on it.  Everyone LOVED the chips (followed a previous suggestion and sprayed with butter, layered, and cut with a pizza cutter -= speeds the process up).  For fruit I used kiwis, mandarin oranges, blueberries, strawberries and raspberries.  It doesn't have a very long shelf life, as the next day it was fairly mushy.

text:
I made this for a 4th of July party.  It went almost uneaten.  That is unfortunate because it actually tasted great.  The cinnamon chips went really well with the fruit.  I can't give it more stars because of the presentation.  The juice from the strawberries and raspberries colored the kiwi and the apples.  The kiwis then turned an unappetizing brown and the apples turned an unrecognizable pink.  The next day I did sit down with the bowl of fruit and the chips and finished them off.  Taste = great.  Presentation = not so much!

text:
I made this for company and a lot of the salsa was left over.  It tasted good, but was way too sweet when combined with the sugary chips.

What was a huge hit was the chips!  People raved over them.  I made another batch and have been eating them as a lighter dessert for about a week.  If they are allowed to fully cool, they stay nice and crisp stored in a Ziplock bag.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Could it get any better?  I don't think so.  I used my chopper to make quick work of the strawberries and Fuji apple and diced 3 kiwi by hand.  Left out the raspberries, but used raspberry preserves and a T. of sugar.  Oh, and I added a squirt of lemon juice for the sake of the apple.  Even good the next day, albeit a bit juicy.  The chips, well, I can't imagine using 2 cups of cinnamon sugar.  I just made 1 cup (with a t. cinnamon) for 10 tortillas (which I sprayed with regular nonstick spray on both sides and then dredged both sides in the sugar) and that was plenty, even making the chips a bit too sweet.  Super easy and tasty, a great snack on their own.  Altogether, a definite keeper.  Thanks!

Excellent recipe!  I used granny smith apples instead of golden delicious, however.  TO make the cinnamon chips, I stacked my tortillas and cut the stack into six triangles each, placed them on a cookie sheet, sprayed them with PAM, and sprinkled the cinnamon sugar on them.  Next time I will probably coat both sides of the chips as they turned out rather bland.

text:
I made this for a bunko party and everyone loved it!! I used apples, strawberries, cherries, kiwi, mango, and blackberries. I also used an egg slicer to dice the strawberries and kiwis. It was pretty messy, but not nearly as bad as doing it by hand would have been. I pitted the cherries and then quartered them, along with the blackberries. For the apples I used a peeler-corer-slicer and that made it much easier! I didn't add any preserves, but i did coat it with a little bit of the leftover cinnamon-sugar mixture. It was a huge hit, everyone asked for the recipe!!

text:
My *only* complaint about this recipe is that the salsa became very unattractive visually after an hour or so, even after adding lemon juice to slow the browning. On my second attempt, I replaced all of the sugar with an extra tablespoon of preserves and 2 tbsp. lemon juice, and that helped a bit without affecting the flavor. The combination of the cinnamon chips with the fruit is WONDERFUL. This is a definite keeper.

text:
Delicious!  It was a hit with the family at Easter Dinner, a nice change.  In the future I will dice the fruit using an egg slicer and hold off on the preserves and sugar until about 15 minutes before I am ready to serve. It does create a lot of juice if you add the sugar too far ahead. I sprayed the tortillas with butter flavored spray, sliced them and then tossed them in a ziploc bag with the cinnamon sugar mixture.  This saved a lot of time.  The kids liked helping with this recipe. A new favorite!

text:
Can not keep my hands off of the cinammon chips.  YUMMYY!!!  I did brush on real melted butter instead of spray flavoring for the tortilla chips.  I just don't eat fake anything.  Prefer the real thing.  And on my pampered chef stone, it took the chips more like 13-15 minutes to bake.  As far as the salsa went, it too is very yummy and VERY sweet (I may cut the sugar next time).  I used a diced mango, lb of strawberries, small box of raspberries, 2 kiwis and 2 apples.  I also used raspberry preserves.  YUMMY!  My youngest wanted a dollup of it over his vanilla yogurt and he gobbled it all up.  This recipe is a keeper.

text:
I made it for a party and everyone was impressed.  I made the fruit dip without any sugars using only the preserves and it was plenty sweet.  To make the chips quickly I covered a few tortillas with butter spray at a time and then cut through a few of them at once with a  pizza cutter.  Then I quickly put each one in the cinnamon/sugar.  I also suggest not to cover the chips with too much cinnamon/sugar and it will still be very sweet when you eat it with the fruit.  Next time I might try using some different fruits to change up the flavor.

text:
These were very very good. When I cut the apples, I squeezed some lemon juice on them to keep them from turning brown. I added frozen peaches instead of raspberries and also used orange marmalade and no added sugar to the fruit, as another reviewer suggested. I also put my fruit in a small hand chopper to speed up the preparation. With the chips, instead of baking them, I put them under the broiler for a few minutes, then flipped them over and put them under the broiler again, then turned out perfectly crisp and browned. Great recipe!

What a great recipe! I made this for a party appetizer and everyone loved it! I added blueberries for some more color and cut back on the sugar. I used black-raspberry jam which added a fun flavor to the salsa. I would suggest using the butter spray on the chips, I didn't have any and used a thin spread of butter on them instead...the chips didn't crisp up very well.

userID:
870570
Display Name:
RecipeAddict
isPro:

38

201

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/101164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM!!  Loved it even more this time than last.  I used Gala apples, which were delicious and I added them last to prevent browning.  For the preserves I used peach, which was great.  Next time I think I'll only do 1Tbs. of each sugar.  It was certainly sweet enough between the fruit, sugar, preserves and chips.  For the tortillas I used fresh tortillas from our local Mexican market (16-perfect amount) and they made absolutely delicious chips.  I did find that the baking time was a little longer than noted and they needed to be flipped half way through for the best crisping.  While they were much better than store bought, they did take a lot of time but are definitely worth the time if you have it!  I will say that an egg slicer would make the chopping of the fruit much much quicker!  By far my favorite fruit salsa recipe.

text:
I just made this tonight and WOW it is so tasty! I have it in the fridge for tomorrow though because it's my daughters 1st bday and I'm having a party. I didn't add the raspberries though from previous reviews and also because I just couldn't find any but I added raspberry preserves and it tastes great so far and that's without the apple added! I'm adding that tomorrow before I serve it. I also added nectarines.. :-) The cinnamon chips are the best though! I wasn't sure why everyone was raving about them and now I know why! They are fantastic! and super easy to make too! I might make just those in the future. I used a regular vegetable oil spray. I figured I just needed that so that the sugar and cinnamon would stick to the tortillas. I used a pizza cutter too and cut more than 1 tortilla at a time and used a muffin form to make a scoop and that is great! :-) Mmm!! thanks for the great recipe! I can't wait for my guests to try it!
update: my guests really liked it. I didn't get asked for the recipe or anything but they asked what was in it. no one really touched the cinamon chips though which was sad! they are good. I think everyone thought I bought them at the store. haha! I'm happy with this recipe though :) It went great along with the Tres Leches cake recipe I found on this site.

Just made it for a cook out today. This was so yummy! I tweaked it a bit and added some fresh pineapple and used a red delicious apple. I also mixed the splenda sweetened orange marmalade and raspberry preserves, a tiny bit of key lime juice and it didn't even need the sugar. I also used the cinnamon sugar pita chips since I was pressed for time. The party is over and my toddler and I are just eating the rest of the salsa with big 'ol spoons!

text:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about tis recipe, but I found it to be okay.  I did make the recipe ahead of time by about 4 hours and it seemed to be a little on the mushy side, so I don't recommend making it too far in advance.  It was good, but from the rating and reviews I thought it would be outstanding, which in my opinion it was not.  I served it with a fajitas thinking it might compliment the Mexican dish since I found the recipe in that category.

This was excellent!  I made it for a bridal shower.  I doubled the fruit, but not the sugar, and it was still sweet and delicious.  I also chopped up some frozen peaches in place of the raspeberries, and I used raspberry preserves.  The chips were a bit time consuming and messy, but good nonetheless.  Next time I will try and buy them.  I will make this again next month for another bridal shower at my office!

text:
This recipe was a big hit. Everyone loved it and wanted the recipe. The only change that I made was I added blueberries to the salsa and I won't do that again because the blueberries tended to roll off the the tortilla wedges. Next time I will try a chopped up fresh peach instead. I also used the apricot preserves and it had wonderful flavor. If you're not serving it where small children are going to be eating it, I would even add a tablespoons of peach schnapps. YUM!

text:
This recipe won 1st place in our families traditional christmas eve cook off. The tortilla chips were worth the extra effort. After spraying the tortillas with the butter spray and cutting them I put them all in a big bowl with the cinnamon and sugar and put a lid on it and shook it. The wedges were coated and it was very easy. We were all surprised by the taste of the salsa. even better then the recipe sounded.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never received so many request for a recipe as to when I serve this fruit salsa. I received a similar recipe years ago at an apple farm, and I have added and changed here and there for several years. I make this all year long with the seasonal fruit on hand. In the winter, I use raspberry preserves and more apples and fresh cranberries diced, with chopped clementines. In the summer, I switch to apricot preserves with apples, kiwi, strawberries, blueberries, papaya, and mango. Then I switch it back up with peach preserves and an all berry mix (black, blue, straw, and rasp.). In that case, I use powdered sugar instead of brown.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times and everyone loves it!  I use a food processer for the fruit which makes it quick and easy - just put the firmest fruit (apples) on the bottom and pulse a few times.  This does tend to puree some of the fruit but it solves the problem of having it get runny and having to be drained. I use kitchen shears to cut the tortillas into wedges and bake on a regular cookie sheet. (I tried an insulated cookie sheet and did not have good luck with it)  I use this recipe freguently and always get many requests for the recipe.

AUSTINRECIPELADY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!!  I've probably made it half a dozen times.  The first couple of times, I followed the recipe exactly, but have also "played" with it as need be.  Once, I was in a real hurry and just did not have time it takes to do all of the cutting.  I just used drained frozen sweetened strawberries and canned crushed pineapple (sweetened), then briefly pulsed some bagged apple slices with some maraschino cherries.  Added a little raspberry preserves and voila... quick fruit salsa.

I lay out long layers of foil upon which to spray and cut my tortillas, then shake them in the cinnasugar mix in a big baggie.

This method is a quick fix, but the original recipe still rocks and is my favorite way to do the recipe when I have the time.

country:
None
text:
What a wonderful, different and refreshing recipe!  I made this for my in-laws 4th of july party and to my shock, the people who normally detest fruit loved it!  For the salsa, I had to omit strawberries due to allergies.  I instead added drained crushed pineapple and peaches. The mixture will become watery as some reviewers noted because that is what sugar does to fruit.    I cooked my chips about 5 minutes longer to make them cripier.  

I am going to try something different next time.  I'm going to use ramakins, spray a whole tortillia, cover it with sugar and cinnamon and bake it upside down on the ramikin. Hopefully, if it turns out, I'll add a scoop of vanilla ice cream and top it with the salsa!

text:
I didn't use Pam on the tortilla chips, but used melted butter instead, since that is what I had on hand.  I used the kiwi's as directed, used one red apple, and one green apple, I chopped up the raspberries instead of leaving them whole, added a mango as others suggested, cut the sugar in half and used apricot fruit preserves.  This definatly took longer to prepare than stated, with all the chopping and such. Granted, my tortilla chips took longer because I used butter instead of Pam.  But I didn't have any, so I improvised.  My husband loved this recipe and has already asked when I will be making this again.  PS - This is an extremly versitile recipie and any amount and combination of fruit could be used.

text:
My sister gave me a similar recipe featured on her local tv station. Here are a few tips:
1) use Splenda instead of the white sugar
2) we like the combination of 1 Granny Smith (tart,crunchy) and 1 Braeburn or Fuji apple (softer, sweet)
3) her recipe called for cinnamon sugar pita chips, I can't locate these so I use nabisco Harvest Crisps and simply add cinnamon to the salsa.

Yummy!

text:
Every time I've brought this to an event or get-together, it's gotten rave reviews and everyone wants the recipe. It's simple and easy to make, but does require some time to cut up the fruit and bake the chips. For the chips, instead of cooking spray I used real melted butter and just brushed it onto the tortillas, then followed with the cinnamon sugar over that. The chips baked up just fine - very tasty and crispy. This is a recipe I'll be using many more times!

text:
This is really tasty but very time consuming.  I would suggest making up the tortilla chips ahead of time if you can.  Also, they take up a lot of room on the cookie sheet.  We used two sheets, two different times, and only were able to make 8 - 10" tortilla.  The cinnamon sugar recipe is way more than you need.  You could also use the fried cinnamon strips recipe if you choose.

text:
My friend Brandy recommended fruit salsa from this website and I'm glad she did.  For a refreshing and delicious desert, this recipe is terrific.  My mother did much the same thing for strawberry shortcake topping.  We topped our French vanilla ice cream with the fruit salsa.  It was excellent.  This chips are also decent and go well with the salsa, but are probably not five star.  Still, on the strength of the fruit salsa alone, overall, this recipe deserves five stars.  It's simple, but does take some time to cut the fruit up if you don't have a food processor.  Try it.  You'll *like* it.

Very nice light appetizer with colors for the holidays. The second time I made it, I followed the recipe exactly and was extremely pleased. What I like most about the recipe is the ability to vary/add to the suggested fruits.

Sometimes I add no sugar and other times I add a bit of honey (when the fruit is not as sweet as usual) and I have thrown in other fruits like peaches and pineapple on occasion.  You just can go wrong with this dish.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-07-05T14:57:44.447
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
13277504
Display Name:
Lexi O
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
22
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice recipe. I used strawberry preserves. The sugar balanced the tartness of the raspberries, but I only put in a little bit (maybe a tsp of brown and white sugar each, same for the preserves). It helped keep the apples from turning brown.  I made the chips too, but cooked them a little longer to make them crisper. I also sprayed the pan itself first with butter spray and then layer the tortillas down on top, with a direct spray on them after that. Less messy that way, and found that I didn't need to use very much butter spray. The chips were a hit and I made a batch that was just salt (kosher) to go with a seven layer dip. I cooked my chips 11 minutes and cut them into 1-2 inch strips (no need to flip them while cooking).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times now and I like it because it's one of those recipes that folks can make their own. 
I did not add sugar to my mix and used strawberry honey jam...just a bit to bind everything together. I tried making the tortilla chips and they take too much work and only come out ok. I found they were impossible to bake "just right". Mine were either under done and wimpy or over and a bit burned tasting.  Now I just buy cinnamon sugar pita chips and they are so much better! Also, when it comes to chopping the fruit, just throw them in a food processor for a couple of pulses. I generally buy a small tub of mixed berries and a tart apple. A little goes a long way with this recipe!

text:
I used this recipe for a cooking class at 4-H camp this summer with campers ranging in age fro 12-18.  Our first lesson was on slicing and dicing, so this was a great recipe to use with all the fruits that get added.  We found a strawberry jalapeno jam that added just the right amount of kick to the salsa.  We went light on the sugars, and we added a little lemon juice to keep the apples from browning .  Because we were short of time, I just sprayed all of the sliced tortillas at once and tossed them with cinnamon sugar and spread them out as evenly as I could on the baking sheet.  We had some stick together, but the final result was enjoyed by not only the campers in the class, but also by the volunteers who got to try to leftovers!

Fun and easy to make and was devoured by my bunco club! text:
I have always come back to this recipe because it is so good. But recently with everyone going to healthier options, I decided to make this a healthier option as well. It's gluten, dairy, and soybean free. I make the salsa with coconut sugar and simply fruit preserves only. Makes it taste just like the original. Instead of tortillas  I use white corn tortillas. Don't spray. anything with an aerosol but use Smart Balance butter soybean free- sprinkle with coconut sugar and cinnamon mix. You do have to cook the corn tortillas a little longer to get them to crisp. Mine took 10-11 mins. Good Luck

I made this for a party last night. I diced up 1 Granny Smith Apple, 1 Fugi Apple and 1# srawberries, 1 pint raspberries and 1/2 pint blueberries. Mi plan to mix leftovers into yogurt for snack. Probably won't make again

text:
TIP: Do NOT use brown or coconut sugar in place of white sugar. It ruins the beautiful red color and you cannot get it back. I used strawberry all-fruit for the preserves and the salsa was amazing! It tasted perfect, perfect balance of strawberry sweetness and tartness from the kiwi and (Fuji) apples. Only problem, few tried it at the party because of unfortunate appearance. My family and I will enjoy it just fine, just don't make the same mistake.

userID:
5973339
Display Name:
TONIWISE68
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
148
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stuff is addicting.  I make it a lot.  What I've learned is you can pretty much use any combination of berries and fruit and its always awesome.  You don't have to use exactly what's listed.  I usually go a little simpler with just the apples, strawberries and raspberries with a blackberry or blueberry preserve.  If you are short on time or just don't feel like chopping fresh fruit I have found that a bag of frozen berries works just as well.  I also tend to go a little heavy on the cinnamon sugar, personal preference.  If you use the small tortillas, lay down a sheet of tin foil and spray some of the butter cooking spray on it then lay a tortilla in the spray, spray the top of the tortilla then put another tortilla on top of that one then spray it and continue stacking that way you get both the top and bottom with less work.  Then just cut through the entire stack.  Following that I sprinkle cinnamon sugar on them  as I take them off the stack and put them on the tray to go in the oven.  Its the quickest, easiest and least messy process I've found for making these.

5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2368110.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe and now have made my own variation that is requested time and time again.  Sugars and fruit preserves as it adds to the sweetness and I just don't think it needs it.  Granny Smith apples, kiwi, pineapple, and strawberries is my fruit mixture - be sure to cut small - the citrus in the pineapple keeps the apples from browning but I will sometimes squeeze some fresh lemon into the mixture.  Dice up all fruit, add a tsp of cinnamon to fruit mixture and refrigerate for a few hours.  Serve with homemade chips or do what I do a lot and buy the Stacy's Cinnamon & Sugar pita chips in the chip aisle.... so fresh, sooo good!  My kids would rather eat this for dessert over cakes and cookies!

We like ours less chunky, so I use the food processor for a more salsa-like consistency.  I highly recommend blackberries in place of the raspberries and I usually eliminate the apple. text:
Every year I make this for a Christmas buffet, there is never any left over! I use bananas, kiwis, honey crisp apples, and strawberries. For the jelly, I use red raspberry preserves with the seeds (any brand) it is a nice substitute for actual raspberries because I find the raspberries get mushy. Plus, the red raspberry preserves make the apples taste like candy apples! Love it!

I followed this recpe as it was written except I didn't have raspberries which I think would have given it a better colour. I thought it was over all OK-OK until I added a large splash of amaretto liqueur and that made a BIG difference.  You really have to watch the tortillas in the oven or they'll burn. If I ever make this again, I will: 1. follow what some said to coat the tortillas on both sides wiht sugar/cinnamon and 2. Add raspberries and maybe some brandied peaches!

country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  As a pregnant woman, I confess I had hoped it would be better, but it is really good.  I forgot to buy apples at the store, so I didn't use those, and no kiwis either.  To help replace the bulk, I did add frozen peaches and pineapple.  Also, after reading other reviews, I left out the sugar, and then used "less-sugar" apricot preserves.  I might prefer it a teensy bit sweeter, because the raspberries are so sour. Also, aside from the raspberries and blueberries, I pulsed everything else in the food processor, and they came out fine-- not crushed or soupy.  I really will try to remember to grab apples when I'm out today to add later-- I look forward to their contribution to this colorful and light snack!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2299558.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a Halloween brunch and it was amazing!  I used 8-inch tortillas, sprayed each side with butter spray, and mixed them with cinnamon sugar in a gallon sized plastic bag.  Then I used a pizza cutter and cut the tortillas into eighths (like a pizza). I baked them for ten minutes and let sit for about a half hour - they were perfect! I liked using the 8-inch tortillas because they were smaller once cut, more like a chip.  For the salsa I mixed kiwi, raspberry, blackberry, apple, and peaches, then a little raspberry jam and some sugar.  Everyone loved it!!!

text:
made this at a party and there were no leftovers. i used strawberry jam. My only suggestion when making the chips is spraying the tortilla with butter first, then placing the tortilla in a bag with the sugar and cinnamon and shaking it until it's fully coated on one side. Do not spray with butter again otherwise chips will come out soggy and not crispy.

text:
I made this twice in 2 days, each time for a different pot luck.  The first time I omitted the white sugar, served it with cinnamon graham crackers and it was great!  Not thinking it could get any better, the next day I took the time to make the cinnamon chips and it was even better!  The second time I used less apple, and more berries, just to my personal taste.....I will use this one again!  FYI, the hint about using the sink to stack 4 tortillas at a time in to eliminate mess was pure genius!  I took it one step further and lined the sink with aluminum foil....just wad it up & throw away when done!

text:
This recipe is awesome.  It's not even so much the exact ingredients, but the idea itself.  I didn't have the same fruits so I used what I had on hand--including pineapple like the previous post--and it was delicious.  I think it would be really fun to make for a party or potluck.  It doesn't keep very long so I put the leftovers in crepes the next morning.  Now it's got me thinking about other ways I could make homemade chips--like garlic and parmesan.  I love that the chips taste just as good as or better than store bought and they're not fried.

text:
This was excellent! I don't really care for raspberries, so I substituted blueberries instead. I also cut down the white sugar to 1 tablespoon as previous reviewers had recommended. It would have been way too sweet otherwise. For the chips, make sure you actually mix the cinnamon and sugar together before sprinkling it over the tortillas. I figured I would sprinkle each separately and the cinnamon ended up burning. When you use the mix, they come out perfectly!  My only other issue is that it came out a bit runny. Not sure how to fix this. Otherwise, a great recipe!

text:
*Edit--made it with 1 less Tbs white sugar, and it's still amazing and perfectly sweet!--This salsa is outstanding!  I've had one before and went searching for the recipe, and this is a great one.  I didn't have raspberries but had a couple of nectarines that needed used, so I substituted them.  The result was better than I could have imagined.  It tasted wonderful and really rounded out the color!  I also used apricot preserves.  I can't imagine docking this recipe stars because of the labor...anything that calls for this much chopping is obviously going to take a little time!  I always make up the time by buying my cinnamon pita chips but will definitely try making these tortillas next time.

Also, my toddler really likes this, but it is difficult for her to scoop out the salsa, so we add the salsa to vanilla yogurt and she LOVES it!

text:
Oh my goodness.  I don't usually write reviews of recipes, because I typically tinker with them a bit to suit my tastes.  But since I had never made a fruit salsa, I thought I would just follow the recipe as it was.  Absolutely delicious.  My husband and I went through half the bowl for dessert tonight, and he was eating it with a spoon after we ran out of chips.  The only caution I have is to make sure you keep an eye on the chips...I over-cooked the first batch, and although they weren't burnt, because the sugar got over cooked it had that nasty bitter taste and I had to throw the whole batch out.    I hope to make this often-I'm sure it would be phenomenal over angel food cake or shortbread.    Delicious recipe Annie-thanks for sharing!!

text:
I rated this 5 stars because of the ease and tastefulness of the recipe. I've made this a few times and I found that making the cinnamon chips took the longest. I've tried many types of tortillas for the cinnamon chips: wheat, spinach, whole grain, and they all turned out great. Instead of sugar, I used 3 coffee-sized packets of Splenda.  When I'm in a big rush, I just pick up a bag of cinnamon apple chips at the market - then the recipe only takes 10 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times.  I enjoy it very much with minor modifications.  The first time I made this, I liked the overall taste, but had the following issues: the salsa was way too sweet for my liking, it had too much liquid, and the cinnamon chips were a pain to make.  Since then, I have made it without adding the white sugar (reducing the sugar also makes it less "soggy" since the liquid is not drawn out of the fruit) and substituting store bought cinnamon pita chips for homemade-- they're much more convenient and, in my opinion, taste better and have a texture suited to this recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
BRWNEYEGRL46
isPro:

followersCount:
8

madeRecipesCount:
63
favoritesCount:
435
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3056.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic!  I made this for a party and it was great.  I made the chips by spraying 1 side of the tortilla with butter flavored spray, cut them with a pizza cutter and dredged them through the cinnamon sugar (1 c. sugar to 1/2 T. cinnamon).  I did the first batch doing both sides but the side facing the cookie sheet remained sticky.  2 trays for 12 minutes at 350 worked great.

The salsa I used 2 pounds strawberries, 1 mango, 3 kiwis, and a can of drained crushed pineapple.  I reserved ~1/2 c. of the juice and mixed that into the fruit with 1 T. brown sugar and 3 T. strawberry jam.  It was just right.  I cut everything Friday, mixed Saturday.  Today is Monday and it still tastes good.  The extras will be pureed and made into fruit leather.  Will make again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-07-28T03:47:47.51

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good. I just chopped up the fruit by hand. I made some changes as well after trying it once or twice. First, I wouldn't put any extra sugar in there besides the brown sugar. Second, I saved some time by spraying 3 tortillas at a time with the butter and then sprinkling them with the cinnamon/sugar and THEN cutting them. I only put a bit of butter and cinnamon/sugar on them or they started to stick to the pan during baking. Also, I only let them bake for 4-5 minutes or they got burnt. They get more crispy as they cool. Overall, a great and tasty recipe I will make many more times.

text:
This was wonderful...I do have to say I did not follow the recipe well, but more the idea...as suggested, I reduced sugar (about 2 tsp brown sugar, no white) and no preserves.  I added some orange muscat vinegar instead of some lemon juice to reduce browning of the apple and for a little zip- yum!  I would also try a good, aged balsamic next time.  For fruit, I used frozen mixed berries, apples, a leftover peach, and some leftover frozen mango.  The chips really made it!  I used Smart Balance  Over all, a great hit with me, 11 yr old boy, and dad.  A great, pretty healthy dessert and great way to use leftover fruit!

text:
I've made these not using this exact recipe and it's delicious. You can use any fruit...cranberries, mixed berries and orange is another good mix. One thing I will say is you really don't need any preserves or the brown sugar either. Maybe just a little br. sugar but not much. Save on the extra sugar and just eat it  natural. You won't be disappointed and neither will your friends...unless you eat it all. My usual mix is...2 oranges, gala apple, granny smith apple, pineapple peaches and strawberries from frozen mix bag. Delicious!

text:
This is a great recipe. I brought it to a girls night and got a great response to it. I didn't add any sugar, and used homemade strawberry jam. It was plenty sweet without the sugar. I didn't have quite enough raspberries, so added some frozen peaches which I let thaw in a strainer to eliminate some of the juices. The apples I plunged into lemon water for a second before adding to the salsa and they didn't turn brown. I don't use anything in an aerosol can, so lightly brushed melted butter over the tortillas and it worked well. I'll definitely use this recipe again.

text:
This recipe was so simple and delicious! I used the required apples, kiwi, and strawberries, but raspberries were expensive, so I used apricots instead. Next time, I would add only 1 Tablespoon of white sugar to the fruit mixture since the chips are so sweet on their own. I did like the juice the sugar creates, making the fruit mixture more salsa-like. As for the tortillas, only one cup of cinnamon sugar was needed. These could be a great snack on their own! Great recipe!

text:
WOW!  Thank you Ann!  This was a fabulous recipe -- and so easy to make.  If I were able to give the recipe 10 stars, I would.  I made it for a wedding shower, and not even 10 minutes into the event, three people asked for the recipe.  Since the shower was held at work, and I had to prepare everything the night before, I was afraid to make the tortilla crisps, for fear they might get soggy or stale, or taste like the plastic Ziplock bag I'd store them in.  Instead, I bought two bags of the Flat Earth chips (in the regular chip aisle at the grocery store) -- one in Blueberry Patch, and the other in Peach Mango Paradise flavor.  The different colors of the chips resembled the multi-colored tortilla chips often served in Mexican restaurants, and paired really nicely with the salsa.  (The chips were a huge hit too!)  I used another reviewer's suggestion to slice the kiwis and strawberries with an egg slicer.  Worked great.  Thanks again for a lovely recipe.  It earned me a few complimentary titles including "domestic goddess" and "Martha Stewart" of the office.  :-)

I thought my kids would go crazy for this as an afternoon snack. But for some reason they didn't like the chips. Simply amazing. I made this for cinco de mayo for the rest of my family, and they loved it. Although I didn't have any kiwis, I found that any fruit works great with it, although apples are a must. I used peaches, strawberries, and apples.

text:
WOW!!  This is a fantastic appetizer/dessert!  It was the hit of a party we just had, and I think every single person there asked me to forward the recipe!  Next time I will add a bit less sugar in the salsa, as I would have liked it a little more tart. I also don't think the preserves were necessary.  For the cinnamon sugar, I used 2 cups of sugar and 1/2 Tbsp cinnamon.  Also, 8 minutes in the oven was perfect for the chips, 10 min. was too long.  Will make this again and again and again... even if my guests don't force me to!

I went to my first Cinco de Mayo party tonight and didn't know what to bring. I found this recipe and tried it on everyone and it was a big hit. It took me around 30 minutes or less to cut up the fruit and finish the fruit salsa.  Very good and very easy. My kids ate several of them before we even left for the party. They were extremely easy to make and a big hit. Thanks!
